question: Who gave the expanding universe hypothesis? SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Edwin Hubble. The most popular argument regarding the origin of the universe is the Big Bang Theory. It is also called the expanding universe hypothesis. Edwin Hubble, in 1920, provided evidence that the universe is expanding. As time passes, galaxies move further and further apart. Galileo Galilei is known for his contributions to astronomy, particularly with the use of the telescope.

question: Geoid is the ________ of earth. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: shape. The Earth looks spherical in shape, but it is not a perfect sphere. It is slightly ﬂattened at the top and bottom (near the South and North Poles) and bulges at the Equator due to the outward force caused by the rotation of the Earth. The Geoid shape is not perfectly spherical.

question: Which is, by far, the closest dwarf planet orbiting at only 2.8 times Earth’s distance from the sun ? SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, and it is the only dwarf planet located in the inner solar system. It was the ﬁrst member of the asteroid belt to be discovered when Giuseppe Piazzi spotted it in 1801.

question: A ________ is a cloud of dust and gas inside a galaxy. SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: nebula. A nebula is an interstellar cloud of dust, hydrogen, helium and other ionized gases. Originally, nebula was a name for any diffuse astronomical object, including galaxies beyond the Milky Way.

question: A distinctive cross - shaped constellation best seen in the northern hemisphere during the summer and fall months around September is: SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Cygnus. It is a northern constellation on the plane of the Milky Way, deriving its name from the Latinized Greek word for swan.

question: The colour of the surface of Mars is red because of the presence of large amounts of chemical compounds in it. What is the name of that compound ? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Iron oxide. Mars appears reddish due to the presence of ferric iron in the form of red hematite (Fe2O3). The surface pressure of Mars is 610 Pascals, and its gravity is about one - third of Earth's. A Martian day lasts 24 hours and 37 minutes. Mars has two moons: Phobos and Deimos.

question: Which dwarf planet orbits the sun in 310 years at a distance between 38.5 to 53 AU ? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Makemake. It is the third-largest and second-brightest known dwarf planet. It was discovered in 2005. Pluto was discovered in 1930. It was initially classiﬁed as the ninth planet of the Solar System but was reclassiﬁed as a dwarf planet in 2006. Pluto has a natural satellite named 'Charon'.

question: Which of the following is the second nearest star to Earth? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Proxima Centauri. It is the closest star to the sun, at a distance of 4.24 light - years. A light - year is the distance light travels in one year, which is about 9.461 x 1012 kilometers. Polaris (North Star) is located nearly directly above Earth's North Pole along its rotational axis. Sirius (Dog Star) is the brightest star in Earth's night sky. Delta Velorum is a triple star system in the southern constellation of Vela.

question: Which of the following statements most accurately describes the planet Saturn? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)

options.A: It is a gas giant made up mostly of
options.B: Its surface is reddish in colour.
options.C: It was the seventh planet discovered
options.D: Its cloud-like outer regions consist of

solution.correct_answer: A. It is a gas giant made up mostly of
solution.explanation: Saturn's density (0.70 gm/cm3) is less than that of water, making it the least dense planet in the solar system. If there were a body of water large enough, Saturn would theoretically ﬂoat. The presence of methane and ammonia is more characteristic of Uranus and Neptune.

question: Which of the following is NOT a moon of Jupiter ? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Triton (largest moon of neptune). Jupiter: It is the ﬁfth planet from the Sun. Revolution - 11 years and 11 months, Rotation - 9 hours 56 minutes. Natural Satellites of planets (As of October 2024) - Jupiter (95), Saturn (146), Earth (1, Moon), Uranus (28), Neptune (16).

question: Which of the following rocky planets is the fastest planet in our solar system – traveling through space at about 29 miles (47 kilometers) per second? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Mercury. It is the nearest to the sun. It takes only about 88 days to complete one round along its orbit. Venus: It is considered as ‘Earth’s - twin’ because its size and shape are very much similar to that of the earth. Venus is also known as Lucifer. Earth is the ﬁfth largest planet (in size). It is slightly ﬂattened at the poles and its shape is described as a Geoid. Mars - The fourth planet from the Sun and it is a dusty, cold, desert world with a very thin atmosphere.

question: Which of the following planets’ atmosphere is made up of thick white and yellowish clouds of sulphuric acid ? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Venus, the second planet from the Sun, is the hottest and known as the "morning star." Mars' atmosphere is www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography 95.32% carbon dioxide, with methane and sulfur dioxide. Uranus is the coldest planet. The coldest planet in the Solar System is Uranus.

question: Which of the following is one of the largest spiral galaxies? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: NGC 6872, which is one of the largest spiral galaxies, spanning 522,000 light-years across, approximately ﬁve times the size of the Milky Way. It is located 212 million light-years from Earth in the southern constellation Pavo.

question: The length of a day on ______ is approximately 16 hours. SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Neptune. Planet and Day Length in hours: Mercury (1,408), Venus (5,832), Earth (24), Mars (25), Jupiter (10), Saturn (11), Uranus (17). Mercury is nearest to the sun. It takes only about 88 days to complete one round along its orbit.

question: Who was the ﬁrst to develop a mathematical predictive heliocentric model of the solar system ? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Nicolaus Copernicus. Although Aryabhatta (5th century A.D.) hinted at astronomical ideas, Copernicus (1473 - 1543) developed the ﬁrst mathematical heliocentric model, where planets revolved around a ﬁxed Sun. Galileo supported this model, and Johannes Kepler later reﬁned it by introducing elliptical orbits, now known as Kepler's laws.

question: Who calculated the approximate location of the planet Neptune by studying gravity- induced disturbances in the motion of Uranus? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Urbain - Jean - Joseph Le Verrier. He was a French astronomer and mathematician. Neptune is the eighth and most distant planet in our solar system, and it is the second coldest planet. It was discovered in 1846. It is the windiest planet in our solar system. One day on Neptune takes about 16 hours.

question: The point in the orbit of an object (such as a satellite) orbiting the earth that is at the greatest distance from the centre of the earth is known as: SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Apogee. Perigee: The moon's orbit closest to the Earth. Perihelion: The Earth closest to the Sun on 3rd January. Aphelion: The Earth farthest from the Sun on 4th July.

question: A ﬂat ring of small, icy bodies that revolve around the sun beyond the orbit of the planet Neptune is called: SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Kuiper Belt, named after Gerard Kuiper, is a region beyond Neptune in the outer solar system, proposed by him in 1951. The asteroid belt lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.

question: The Big Dipper is an asterism formed by the seven brightest stars in the constellation: SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Ursa Major (Great Bear) is the third - largest constellation in the sky and the largest constellation in the Northern Hemisphere. Orion is three bright stars close together in an almost-straight line. Cassiopeia is a large constellation located in the northern sky. The Leo constellation lies in the northern sky.

question: A constellation of the northern sky easily recognised by a group of ﬁve bright stars forming a slightly irregular ‘W’ is called: SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Cassiopeia. It is a prominent constellation in the northern sky. It is visible during winter in the early part of the night. It looks like a distorted letter W or M.

question: Which planet is the second largest planet in our solar system and also has the biggest and the brightest rings around it ? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Saturn. Our Solar System has eight planets which orbit the sun. In order of distance from the sun they are: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Largest to smallest: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Earth, Venus, Mars, Mercury. Saturn moon Titan is the second largest moon after Ganymede (Jupiter’s moon).

question: _________ oblong orbit overlaps the orbit of Neptune. SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Pluto’s. Neptune is the outermost Jovian planet in the solar system. Until 2006 Pluto was the farthest planet from the Sun. In 2006, The International Astronomical Union (IAU) downgraded the status of Pluto to that of a dwarf planet. The Jovian planets are Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, which are also known as the gas giants.

question: Which of the following statements about planet Saturn is true? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift)

options.A: Saturn is the fourth planet from the
options.B: Satellites like Enceladus and Titan of
options.D: Saturn is a massive ball made up

solution.correct_answer: B. Satellites like Enceladus and Titan of
solution.explanation: Saturn is the second largest planet, composed of hydrogen and helium. It has 146 moons. Titan - It is the largest moon of Saturn and the second largest moon in our solar system. Enceladus - It is the second nearest of the major regular moons of Saturn and the brightest of all its moons. It was discovered in 1789 by the English astronomer William Herschel. It is found that Titan has methane in its atmosphere and Enceladus has a liquid ocean with erupting plumes of gas and water.

question: Which star is also known as the ‘Pole Star’ ? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: The North star. Polaris, also known as the North Star, is located almost directly above Earth's north pole along our planet's rotational axis. The www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography imaginary line that runs through the Earth from the North Pole to the South Pole is called the Earth's axis of rotation. The Earth rotates around this axis, similar to how a top spins around its spindle.

question: In 1905, who concluded with Thomas Chamberlain that the planets of the Solar System originated from an encounter between the Sun and another star? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Forest Moulton. He was an American astronomer and mathematician known for his contributions to celestial mechanics. He co-developed the Chamberlin-Moulton planetesimal hypothesis, which proposed a model for the formation of the solar system. According to this hypothesis, planets formed from smaller bodies called planetesimals through the process of accretion.

question: Perihelion is when Earth is ______. Graduate Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: nearest to the sun. On 3rd January, the earth is the nearest to the sun (147 million km). Aphelion is the point of the Earth’s orbit that is farthest away from the Sun.

question: Which is the most widely accepted model to explain the formation and evaluation of the solar system? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Nebular hypothesis - The planets were formed out of a cloud of material associated with a youthful sun, which was slowly rotating. The theory was developed by Immanuel Kant. But Mathematician Laplace revised it in 1796. Other Hypothesis: Big Bang Theory - Propounded by George Lamaitre related to the origin of the universe.

question: Terrestrial planets are composed of _______. SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)

options.C: metals and gas (d) rocks and gas

solution.explanation: Rocks and metals. Terrestrial Planets - Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars. They are categorised into the following: Silicate Planets, Iron Planets, Coreless Planets, Carbon (diamond) Planets.

question: Which trend is found about the distance between the galaxies? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Increasing. In 1929, Edwin Hubble announced that almost all galaxies appeared to be moving away from us. He found that the universe was expanding - with all of the galaxies moving away from each other. This phenomenon was observed as a redshift of a galaxy's spectrum.

question: On which planet has a rotating oval of clouds, twice as wide as Earth, called the 'Great Red Spot' been observed for more than 300 years ? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system. It is made mostly of hydrogen and helium.

question: Which scientist thought of the concept of the steady state of the universe? SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Fred Hoyle. Steady - State Theory : It is a theoretical model in which the Universe is constantly expanding but with a ﬁxed average density. The theory was put forward by three scientists Sir Hermann Bondi, Thomas Gold, and Sir Fred Hoyle in 1948.

question: Cosmic snowballs of frozen gases, rock and dust that orbit the Sun are known as_______. SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Comets. Meteors are bits of rock and ice that are ejected from comets as they move in their orbits about the Sun. Meteorites - When a meteoroid survives its trip through the atmosphere and hits the ground, it’s called a meteorite. Meteorites typically range between the size of a pebble and a ﬁst.

question: What is the radius of the earth? SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: 6371 km. Earth Distance from the Sun (150 million km), Surface area: 510.1 million km², Land area: 149 million km², Gravity: 9.8 m/s².

question: Each orbit of the International Space Station (ISS) takes _____minutes . SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 90-93. In 24 hours, the space station makes 16 orbits of Earth, traveling through 16 sunrises and sunsets.

question: In approximately how much time does Mars complete one spin on its axis? SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 1 day. One spin on the axis of other planets (approximate) : Earth (1 day - 23 hours 56 min), Jupiter (9 hours 56 minutes), Saturn (10 hours 40 minutes), Uranus (17 hours 14 minutes) and Neptune (16 hours 7 minutes).

question: Which among the following is not a type of solar eclipse? SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Penumbral (Lunar eclipse). A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between the Earth and the Sun. Types of solar eclipse: Total (Completely blocking the face of the Sun), Hybrid (the Moon is farther away from Earth, it appears smaller than the Sun and does not completely cover the Sun) and Annular (when Sun is at or near its farthest point from Earth).

question: In early 1610, who discovered with his newly invented telescope that Jupiter has four moons? SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Galileo Galilei. He was an Italian astronomer and scientist. He described the rings of Saturn, the phases of Venus, sunsets, and the bumpy lunar surface. The four moons he discovered were: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.

question: Who was the ﬁrst to accurately describe the rings of Saturn as a disc around the planet in 1655? SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (4th Shift) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

solution.explanation: Christiaan Huygens. His other inventions include the pendulum clock, centrifugal governor, and magic lantern.

question: The moon completes _________ rotation on its axis as it completes one revolution around the Earth. SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 1. The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite circling the planet at an average distance of 384,400 kilometers. The Moon's presence helps stabilize our planet and moderate our climate. The radius of the Moon is 1.74 × 106 m. Huygens is the Moon's tallest mountain.

question: Which of the following statements regarding the moon is correct? I. The size of the illuminated part of the moon visible from the Earth increases each day after the new moon day. II. After the full moon day, the sunlit part of the moon visible from the Earth decreases in size every day. SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Both I and II. When there are two full moons within a month, the second full moon is called a Blue Moon, When a full moon occurs at its perigee (the moon is closest to the earth) it is called a Supermoon.

question: The ______ radiation belts are giant swaths of magnetically trapped highly energetic charged particles that surround Earth. SSC CGL 13/04/2022(Morning)

solution.explanation: Van Allen. An aurora is a natural phenomenon which is characterized by a display of a natural-coloured (green, red, yellow or white) light in the sky.

question: In which of the following periods is the meteor shower named Quadrantids generally visible from Earth? SSC MTS 20/10/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: December / January. Quadrantids are best viewed in the Northern Hemisphere during the night and predawn hours. They are also known for their bright ﬁreball meteors. The Quadrantids can produce over 100 meteors per hour in a moonless sky.

question: In which of the following months may the meteor shower named Lyrids be seen from Earth? SSC MTS 20/10/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: April. The radiant point for the Lyrid meteor shower is near the constellation Lyra, which has the bright star Vega in the east.

question: How many degrees does the Earth rotate about its own axis in one hour? SSC CGL 06/03/2020(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 15. On its axis, the earth rotates 360 degrees every 24 hours. Longitudes and Latitudes

question: The torrid zone lies between ____. SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024

options.C: Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of
options.D: Arctic Circle and Tropic of Cancer

solution.correct_answer: C. Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of
solution.explanation: Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn. The Torrid Zone is the thermal zone located between the Tropic of Cancer (23.5°N) and the Tropic of Capricorn (23.5°S). It experiences high temperatures year-round due to direct sunlight. The Temperate Zones lie between the Tropics and the Arctic Circle (66.5° N) and Antarctic Circle (66.5° S), characterized by moderate temperatures with distinct seasons. The Frigid Zones are found beyond the Arctic and Antarctic Circles, extending to the North and South Poles, where temperatures are extremely cold year-round.

question: At what latitude does the easterly jet stream blow over peninsular India during the summer months? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 14°N. The Jet Stream is a geostrophic wind blowing horizontally through the upper layers of the troposphere, generally from west to east. The tropical easterly jet stream, located between 8 and 35 degrees north latitude, is connected to the southwest monsoon in India.

question: In which month is the InterTropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) located around 20°N-25°N latitude (over the Gangetic plain) ? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: July. The Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is a low pressure zone located at the equator where trade winds converge, and so, it is a zone where air tends to ascend. The Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone located around 20°N-25°N latitudes (over the Gangetic plain) in July month is sometimes called the monsoon trough.

question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the Coriolis force? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)

options.A: It deﬂects the wind to the right in the
options.B: It is directly proportional to the angle
options.C: Deﬂection is less when the wind is
options.D: It is absent at the equator.

solution.correct_answer: C. Deﬂection is less when the wind is
solution.explanation: Deﬂection is less when the wind is high. Coriolis force : An apparent force caused by the earth’s rotation. The Coriolis force acts perpendicular to the pressure gradient force (pressure gradient force is perpendicular to an isobar). It is maximum at the poles and is absent at the equator. The Coriolis force also affects ocean currents.

question: Which is the Standard Meridian of India? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 82°30ʹ E. The Standard Meridian of India, which passes through Mirzapur in Uttar Pradesh, also crosses the following states: Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Andhra Pradesh.

question: Which is the waterbody that separates Andaman Islands and Nicobar Islands? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Ten Degree Channel. The 8 Degree Channel (north latitude) separates the islands of Minicoy (India) and Maldives. The 9 Degree Channel (north latitude) separates the Minicoy www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography from the main Lakshadweep archipelago. The 11 degree channel (north latitude) separates the Amindivi Islands subgroup from the Cannanore Islands in Lakshadweep Islands.

question: Identify a factor that does NOT determine the temperature of ocean waters. Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Longitude. Factors determining ocean water temperature : Latitude - Affects the amount of solar radiation received. Unequal distribution of land and water - Affects heat absorption and distribution. Ocean currents - Transport heat and cold water masses globally. Longitude does not directly inﬂuence ocean water temperature.

question: Which of the following sets of statements are correct about Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) ? a. The ITCZ is a broad trough of low pressure in equatorial latitudes. b. This is where the northeast and the southeast trade winds converge. c. The ITCZ is the equatorial trough normally positioned about 5°N of the equator and remains there throughout the year. d. The ITCZ moves over to the plane of Ganga in Summer. SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: a, b and d. Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) - The region that circles the Earth, near the equator, where the trade winds of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres come together. Seasonal shifts in the location of the ITCZ drastically affects rainfall in many equatorial nations, resulting in the wet and dry seasons of the tropics rather than the cold and warm seasons of higher latitudes.

question: During October-November, the apparent movement of the sun is towards the _____. SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: South. The position of the rising sun keeps on moving towards the south in the period from 21st June to 22nd December. This period is called Dakshinayan. From 22nd December to 21st June, the sun keeps on moving towards the north. This period is called Uttarayan.

question: The southern part of India lies in the _________ belt. SSC MTS 19/06/2023 (Afternoon

solution.explanation: Warm. The Tropic of Cancer passes through the middle of India. The southern parts being closer to the Equator, experience high temperatures throughout the year. The northern parts on the other hand lie in the warm temperate zone.

question: Tropic of Cancer (23°30′ N) passes through__________ state of India. SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Chhattisgarh. The Tropic of Cancer passes through eight states in India - Gujarat (Jasdan), Rajasthan (Kalinjarh), Madhya Pradesh (Shajapur), Chhattisgarh (Sonhat), Jharkhand (Lohardaga), West Bengal (Krishnanagar), Tripura (Udaipur) and Mizoram (Champhai).

question: On which of the following two dates does the equinox fall ? SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: 21 March and 23 September. Equinox is the situation when the equator receives the vertical rays of the Sun and day and night are equal. Spring equinox - 21st March, Autumn equinox - 23 September. 21st June (winter solstice in Southern Hemisphere, Summer solstice in Northern hemisphere) - The rays of the sun fall directly on the Tropic of Cancer. 22 December (Summer solstice in Southern hemisphere, winter solstice in Northern Hemisphere) - The rays of the sun fall directly on the Tropic of Capricorn.

question: From the north most to south most point of India, what is the extent of India? SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: 3214 km. Extent of India: East to west (2,933 km), land frontier (15,200 km), coastline (7,516.6 km). The westernmost point (Ghuar Moti in Kutch). The easternmost point (Kibithu in Arunachal Pradesh). Indira Col (northernmost point). Indira Point (Great Nicobar Island, Andaman sea) is the Southernmost point of India while Kanyakumari is the southernmost point of the Indian Mainland.

question: What is the zone between the arctic circle and north pole called? SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Frigid zone. The North Frigid Zone, between the North Pole at 90° N and the Arctic Circle at 66°33′48.7" N, covers 4.12% of Earth's surface.

question: 1° latitude is equal to approximately ______ km. SSC CHSL 16/10/2020(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 111 km. This distance decreases marginally as one travels to poles and increases marginally as one goes towards the equator.

question: Lines joining located at equal travel time from a common centre are called: SSC CHSL 21/10/2020(Morning)

solution.explanation: Isochrones. Isohaline - A line drawn on a map to indicate connecting points of equal salinity in the ocean. Isonomal - A line on a chart connecting points of equal abundance values of a plant species sampled in different sections of an area. Isobronts - A line drawn through geographical points at which a given phase of thunderstorm activity occurred simultaneously. Continents and Oceans

question: Which is the largest sea located in the North Indian Ocean, covering an area of about 3.86 million square kilometres? SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Arabian Sea. The North Indian Ocean is a region of the Indian Ocean that includes the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea. The Arabian Sea shows higher salinity due to high evaporation and low inﬂux of fresh water. The Red Sea is located between Africa and Asia. The Java Sea is located in Indonesia, www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography between the islands of Java and Borneo. The Andaman Sea is located in the northeastern part of the Indian Ocean.

question: Which of the following is the largest crustal plate on Earth with an area of over 103,000,000 km2? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Paciﬁc plate : It is the largest oceanic plate. Plate Tectonics theory given by McKenzie, Parker and Morgan in 1967. It proposes that the earth’s lithosphere is divided into seven major and some minor plates. Major plates : Antarctica and the surrounding oceanic plate; North American (with western Atlantic ﬂoor separated from the South American plate along the Caribbean islands) plate; South American (with western Atlantic ﬂoor separated from the North American plate along the Caribbean islands) plate; Paciﬁc plate; India-Australia-New Zealand plate; Africa with the eastern Atlantic ﬂoor plate; Eurasia and the adjacent oceanic plate.

question: In the context of water bodies, Neap Tides occur : SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: when the earth, moon and sun line up
options.B: when the sun and moon are on the
options.C: when there is so much interference by
options.D: when the sun and moon are at right

solution.correct_answer: D. when the sun and moon are at right
solution.explanation: During neap tide, gravitational and centrifugal forces are divided. The high tides of a neap tide are lower than the average high tide and the low tides of a Neap tide are higher than the average low tide. Spring tides - When the sun, the moon and the earth are in a straight line, the height of the tide will be higher. These are called spring tides, and they occur twice a month.

question: Which of the following is a landlocked Salt Lake in South-West Asia between Israel and Jordan? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Dead Sea. Its salinity of 340 grams per litre of water. The Dead Sea seawater has a density of 1.240 kg/L, which makes swimming in its waters similar to ﬂoating. The Caspian Sea is the world's largest saltwater lake by volume. The Aral Sea is located between Kazakhstan to the north and Uzbekistan to the south.

question: Which ocean is encircling the continent of Antarctica and extends northward to 60 degrees south latitude? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Southern Ocean. It is the newest of the world's ﬁve oceans, oﬃcially designated as a separate ocean by the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) in 2000. The Atlantic Ocean is between the Americas and Europe/Africa. The Indian Ocean is between Africa, Asia, and Australia. The Paciﬁc Ocean is between Asia and the Americas.

question: The name of the strait between the Paciﬁc and Arctic oceans, separating the Chukchi Peninsula of the Russian Far East from the Seward Peninsula of Alaska, is the : SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Bering Strait. Davis Strait : It is located between Greenland and Baﬃn Island in Canada. It connects Baﬃn Bay with the Labrador Sea and is part of the Northwest Passage in the Arctic. Florida Strait : It is a channel of water located between the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean, separating the Florida Keys and Cuba. Strait of Messina : It is a narrow passage between the eastern coast of Sicily and the western coast of Calabria in southern Italy. It connects the Tyrrhenian Sea with the Ionian Sea.

question: The peninsular plateau of India was a part of which continent earlier? SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Africa. The Peninsular Plateau is roughly triangular in shape. The peninsular plateau of India was a part of the supercontinent Gondwana, which included Africa, South America, Australia, and Antarctica. After breaking up from Gondwana, the Indian subcontinent drifted northwards and collided with Eurasia which formed the Himalayas.

question: In 1596, who suggested in his work 'Thesaurus Geographicus' that the continents of the earth were not always located in their present positions ? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Abraham Ortelius was a Dutch mapmaker who proposed in his work Thesaurus Geographicus that the continents were once joined together. This idea laid the groundwork for the continental drift theory, later fully developed by Alfred Wegener in 1912. Wegener suggested that all continents formed a single landmass called Pangaea ("all earth"), surrounded by a vast ocean known as Panthalassa ("all water").

question: Which of the following is NOT a part of the ocean ﬂoor? Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: The deep sea shelf. A continental shelf is the submerged edge of a continent beneath the ocean. The continental slope extends seaward from the shelf to the upper edge of a continental rise or the point where the slope begins to ﬂatten. An abyssal plain, or deep sea plain, is a ﬂat region on the ocean ﬂoor, typically found at depths between 3,000 and 6,000 meters. Oceanic deeps are the deepest parts of the ocean, covered with ﬁne-grained sediments such as clay and silt. Examples of oceanic landforms : Abyssal plains, Submarine canyons, Deep ocean trenches, Guyots, Seamounts, Mid-ocean ridges, Abyssal plains, etc.

question: The thermocline layer is the ______ layer of the ocean. Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Second. Scientists have divided the ocean into ﬁve main layers. Epipelagic Zone - The surface layer from the surface to 200 meters. Mesopelagic Zone - The twilight zone or the midwater zone. Bathypelagic Zone - The midnight zone or the dark zone. Abyssopelagic Zone - The water temperature is near freezing, and there is no light at all. Hadalpelagic Zone - The deepest point in the ocean is located in the Mariana Trench.

question: In 1962, who published 'The History of Ocean Basins', which outlined the theory of how tectonic plates could www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography move, later called 'sea ﬂoor spreading' ? Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Harry Hammond Hess, an American geologist and naval oﬃcer. He discovered that the oceans were shallower in the middle and identiﬁed the presence of Mid Ocean Ridges, raised above the surrounding generally ﬂat sea ﬂoor (abyssal plain) by as much as 1.5 km. Seaﬂoor spreading is a geologic process in which tectonic plates—large slabs of Earth's lithosphere—split apart from each other.

question: Which is the deepest point of Earth's oceans with a depth of 11,022 metres? Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Paciﬁc Ocean's Mariana Trench. Trenches are long, narrow depressions on the seaﬂoor that form at the boundary of tectonic plates where one plate is pushed, or subducts, beneath another. Other Trenches: Puerto Rico Trench (8,400 m) - Atlantic Ocean; Tonga Trench (10,882 m) - Southwestern Paciﬁc Ocean; South Sandwich Trench (7,432 m) - Southern Ocean; Java Trench (7,187 m) - Indian Ocean.

question: Which of the following is the correct match between column-A and column-B ? Column - A (Elements in earth crust) Column - B (Total % in earth crust) i. Oxygen a. 8% ii. Silicon b. 28% iii. Aluminium c. 47% iv. Iron d. 5% SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: i-c, ii-b, iii-a, iv-d. Abundances of other Element in the Earth’s Crust: Calcium (Ca) - 3.63%, Sodium (Na) - 2.83%, Potassium (K) - 2.59%, Magnesium (Mg) - 2.09% and others - 1.41%. Earth has three layers: crust (upper layer), mantle (middle layer), and core (lower layer).

question: Continental Shelf which is the shallowest part of the ocean has an average gradient of: SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 1° or even less. The Continental Shelf is the extended margin of each continent occupied by relatively shallow seas and gulfs. About Continental Shelf : The shelf typically ends at a very steep slope, called the shelf break. Their width varies globally, with an average of about 80 km, but can be narrower or even absent in some regions, such as the coasts of Chile and the west coast of Sumatra.

question: Living organisms have been on Earth for how much percent of Earth's history? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: 80%. Taking Earth's age as nearly 4.6 Billion Years (BY), instead of 13.7 BY from the Big Bang, unicellular life appeared nearly 3.8 BY ago. This percentage is 3.8/4.6 X 100 = 82.6%, nearly.

question: Choose the correct statement(s) related to ‘continentality’. a. The sea exerts a moderating inﬂuence on climate. b. As the distance from the sea increases, the people experience extreme weather conditions. c. As one goes from the surface of the earth to higher altitudes, the atmosphere becomes less dense and temperature decreases. SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: a and b. Continentality (i.e. very hot during summers and very cold during winters) found in inland areas. Continental climates are common between 40° and 70° north latitude and experience large temperature differences between day and night.

question: What does El Niño refer to ? SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Hot water current. The term El Nino (Little Boy in Spanish) - Warming of the ocean surface, or above-average sea surface temperatures, in the central and eastern tropical Paciﬁc Ocean on the coast of Peru. El nino leads to weakening of trade winds in a region. La Nina (Little Girl in Spanish) - The periodic cooling of ocean surface temperatures in the central and east-central equatorial Paciﬁc.

question: Which of the following oceans is surrounded by the continent of North America and South America to the east? SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Paciﬁc Ocean (world’s largest and deepest ocean): It represents 45 percent of the global ocean surface. The International Date Line (established in 1884) passes through the mid-Paciﬁc Ocean. The Atlantic Ocean is surrounded by the continents of North and South America to the west, and Europe and Africa to the east. The Indian Ocean is bordered by Asia to the north, Africa to the west, and Australia to the east.

question: Which of the following oceans extends into the Mediterranean Sea ? SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Atlantic Ocean is the 2nd largest ocean in the world. The Mediterranean is an intercontinental sea spread between Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia and connected to the Atlantic Ocean through the strait of Gibraltar.

question: The mohororvicic (Moho) discontinuity separates ? SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

options.C: Earth's crust and the inner core

solution.correct_answer: D. Earth's crust and the mantle
solution.explanation: Earth's crust and the mantle. Moho discontinuity - It occurs at an average depth of about 8 kilometers beneath the ocean basins and 32 kilometers beneath continental surfaces.

question: Due to the attraction of the sun and the moon, what is the frequency of up and falls of ocean water in a day ? SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Two. When the Earth, Sun, and Moon line up, their gravitational power combines to make exceptionally high tides where the bulges occur, called spring tides, as well as very low tides where the water has been displaced. www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography When the Sun is at a right angle to the Moon, moderate tides, called neap tides. There are generally three types of tides: Diurnal - One high and low tide each day, Semi-diurnal - Two high and low tides each day, and Mixed - Two high and low tides each day of different heights.

question: Which is the correct sequence of oceans according to size (from largest to smallest) ? SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Paciﬁc Ocean, the world's largest, was named by Ferdinand Magellan. The International Date Line passes through it.

question: The percentage of earth's water found in the oceans is _________. SSC CGL 01/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: 97.2 percent. Water covers 71 percent of Earth's surface. Distribution of Earth’s water: Oceans (97.2%), Glaciers (2.1%), Groundwater (0.61 percent); Freshwater lakes (0.009 percent), Inland seas (0.008 percent), Soil Moisture (0.005 percent), Atmosphere (0.001 percent), Rivers (0.0001 percent). 2.7 % of earth’s water is fresh.

question: How thick is the lithosphere? SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 10 to 200 km. The lithosphere is the outermost and mechanical layer of the Earth that consists of the entire crust and the top-most portion of the mantle. Mechanically, the earth’s layers can be divided into lithosphere, asthenosphere (80-200 km), mesospheric mantle, outer core, and inner core.

question: The crust is the Earth's outermost layer that is less than ______ percent of Earth by mass, with oceanic crust and continental crust often consisting of more felsic rocks. SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: 1. The average density of oceanic crust is 3.0 g/cm3, while continental crust has an average of 2.7 g/cm3. The mass of the continental crust is 2.195. The continental crust (about 30 km) is composed of lighter (felsic) sodium potassium aluminum silicate rocks, like granite. The oceanic crust (about 5 km) is composed of dense (maﬁc) iron magnesium silicate igneous rocks, like basalt.

question: Movement of fault lines can cause: SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: An earthquake. It is a sudden shaking or trembling of the earth which lasts for a very short time. Earthquakes tend to occur at the boundaries of earth’s plates. These boundaries are known as fault zones. Over 80 percent of earthquakes occur around the edges of the Paciﬁc Ocean, an area known as the 'Ring of Fire'. Instrument used for measuring Earthquake: Seismograph.

question: What is the average salinity of the Indian ocean? Graduate Level 03/08/2022 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: 35 o/oo (35 parts per thousand). Salinity is the amount of salt present in 1000 grams of water. A salinity of 24.7 % has been regarded as the upper limit to ﬁx ‘brackish water’.

question: Tsunami is NOT caused by: Higher Secondary 03/08/2022 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Hurricanes. Tsunamis are giant waves caused by earthquakes or volcanic eruptions under the sea.

question: Which of the following is a warm current? SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Gulf stream current in the North Atlantic and the Kuroshio Current in the North Paciﬁc are warm currents. Warm Currents - Alaskan Current, Tsushima Current, Brazilian Current etc. Cold Current - Labrador Current, Canary Current, Benguela Current, Falkland Current, South Indian Ocean Current, Okhotsk Current, Humboldt or Peruvian Current etc.

question: The plate movements on earth are classiﬁed into ______ types. SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: three. The movement of the plates creates three types of tectonic boundaries: convergent, where plates move into one another; divergent, where plates move apart; and transform, where plates move sideways in relation to each other.

question: Ocean acidiﬁcation is the ongoing decrease in the pH of the Earth’s oceans, caused by the uptake of ______ from the atmosphere. SSC MTS 15/07/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Carbon dioxide. Ocean acidiﬁcation is the worldwide reduction in the pH of seawater as a consequence of the absorption of large amounts of carbon dioxide by the oceans. It results in the alteration of marine food chains and food supply to humans.

question: The lowest known point on earth is called ________, which is present in the Paciﬁc Ocean. SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Morning)

options.C: Great Blue Hole (d) Great Barrier Reef

solution.explanation: Challenger Deep. It is located beneath the western Paciﬁc Ocean. Factorian Deep is the new deepest point in Antarctica's Southern Ocean. The Great Blue Hole is a giant marine sinkhole off the coast of Belize. The great barrier reef is the world’s largest coral reef located in Australia.

question: In coastal areas, during the night, wind blows from land to sea because: SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Morning)

options.A: low pressure is created on land
options.D: high pressure is created at sea

solution.correct_answer: C. water cools slower than land
solution.explanation: water cools slower than land. The wind blowing from land towards the sea is the Land breeze. The wind blowing from the sea towards the land is a sea breeze. Both are induced by differences that occur between the heating or cooling of the water surface and the adjacent land surface.

question: The process of seepage of water into the ground is called ____. SSC MTS 25/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Inﬁltration occurs when surface water enters the soil.

question: Which water body covers an area of 1,55,58,000 and makes up only 𝑘𝑚 2 4.3% of the global ocean? SSC CHSL 24/05/2022(Morning)

solution.explanation: Arctic Ocean is the smallest and shallowest of the world's ﬁve major oceans.

question: Which is the largest continental shelf in the world? SSC CHSL 24/05/2022(Evening)

options.C: The shelf in the Paciﬁc Ocean
options.D: The Siberian shelf in the Arctic Ocean

solution.correct_answer: D. The Siberian shelf in the Arctic Ocean
solution.explanation: The Siberian shelf in the Arctic Ocean. A continental shelf is the edge of a continent that lies under the ocean. Example of a Continental Shelf Landform: Siberian Shelf, Arctic Ocean.

question: Which of the following is a group of islands found in the tropical oceans consisting of coral reefs and a central depression? SSC CGL 19/04/2022(Morning)

solution.explanation: Atoll. List of atolls: Great Chagos Bank, Macclesﬁeld Bank, Thiladhunmathi, Sabalana Islands. Guyot is an undersea mountain. Lagoons are shallow bodies of water that are separated from the ocean by a barrier reef. Seamounts are underwater mountains that rise above the ocean ﬂoor but do not reach the surface.

question: Name the only sea in the world that does NOT have a land boundary. SSC MTS 13/10/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Sargasso Sea. It is a part of the Atlantic Ocean. It is named so because of the presence of brown Sargassum seaweed.

question: Which of the following was NOT a part of Gondwanaland? SSC CGL 23/08/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: North America. The ancient supercontinent Gondwana incorporated present-day South America, Africa, Madagascar, India, Australia, and Antarctica.

question: What is the normal air pressure at sea level? SSC CHSL 19/03/2020(Morning)

solution.explanation: 1013.25 millibars. The air pressure decreases as the altitude increases.

question: India is divided into how many earthquake zones (seismic zones)? SSC CHSL 19/03/2020(Morning)

solution.explanation: 4. The Bureau of Indian Standards has classiﬁed regions in India into 4 seismic zones on the basis of historical seismic activity. These are zones II, III, IV and V. Zone V is the most seismically active region and Zone II is the least active. The magnitude scale used to measure earthquakes ranges from 1 to 12.

question: The _____ is responsible for Earth's magnetic ﬁeld. SSC CHSL 16/10/2020(Morning)

solution.explanation: outer core. On Earth, ﬂowing liquid metal in the outer core of the planet generates electric currents. The rotation of Earth on its axis causes these electric currents to form a magnetic ﬁeld which extends around the planet. Neighbouring Countries of India

question: Which of the following is in geographical proximity to Sri Lanka? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.correct_answer: A. Only Karaikal (b) Karaikal and Yanam
solution.explanation: Only Karaikal. Karaikal is a town in the Union Territory of Puducherry. Sri Lanka, formerly known as Ceylon, is an island nation in South Asia. Located in the Indian Ocean, southwest of the Bay of Bengal, it is separated from the Indian peninsula by the Gulf of Mannar and the Palk Strait. Sri Lanka shares a maritime border with the Maldives to the southwest and India to the northwest.

question: Which of the following pairs do NOT share any borders? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Bhutan and Meghalaya. The Indian states of West Bengal (183 km), Arunachal Pradesh (217 km), Sikkim (32 km), and Assam (267 km) share their boundaries with Bhutan. The Kingdom of Bhutan and the Republic of India are separated by a 699 km long, regional border.

question: Which of the following countries has the highest Hindu population after India? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Nepal. After India, the next nine countries with the largest Hindu populations are, in decreasing order : Nepal, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, the United States, Malaysia, the United Arab Emirates and the United Kingdom.

question: The New Moore Island is in geographic proximity to: SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Bangladesh. New Moore Island, also known as South Talpatti, is located in the Bay of Bengal and is geographically closest to Bangladesh. It lies near the maritime boundary between India and Bangladesh.

question: Maldives are located to the south of which island of India? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Lakshadweep. Maldives : Its capital is Male. The Maldives are a group of coral atolls that were formed from the crowns of an ancient volcanic mountain range.

question: McMahon Line is the boundary line between India and _________ . Higher Secondary 21/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: China. Pakistan shares a border with India, deﬁned by the Radcliffe Line (International Border) and the Line of Control. India has 15,106.7 Km of land border and a coastline of 7,516.6 Km including island territories. India shares the longest border with Bangladesh about 4,096.7 km and Shortest with www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography Afghanistan about 106 km. The Durand line separates Pakistan and Afghanistan.

question: Which trek in Bhutan is considered to be the crown jewel of Bhutanese trekking? Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: Snowman Trek. It is a 27 day track. Other Treks in Bhutan - Jumolhari Trek, Dagala Thousand Lakes trek, Laya Gasa Trek, Druk Path Trek, Tsaluna Trek, etc. Treks in India - Kalindi Khal Trek, Stok Kangri Trek, Auden's Col Trek, Chadar Trek, etc.

question: Nepal does NOT share its boundary with which of the following states in India? SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Manipur. Nepal is located to the North of India. It shares a border with ﬁve Indian states: Uttarakhand, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, West Bengal, and Sikkim. The total length of the India-Nepal border is about 1,751 kilometers.

question: With which neighbouring country does India share the Sunderbans forest? SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Bangladesh. Sunderban forest is a part of the world's largest delta and home to the largest mangrove forests. It is the only mangrove habitat in the world for Panthera tigris species.

question: The Sino - Indian border is divided into how many sectors? SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 3. The Indian Military has divided the LAC (Line of Actual Control) into 3 sectors - Western sector across Ladakh and the Chinese-held Aksai Chin, The central sector across Himachal Pradesh and Uttrakhand states, and the eastern sector across Sikkim and Arunachal Pradesh states.

question: Which of the following is a hill pass located between India and China? SSC MTS 26/10/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Karakoram Pass. The Khyber Pass is a mountain pass in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan, on the border with Afghanistan. Pangsau Pass lies on the crest of the Patkai Hills on the India–Myanmar border. Zojila Pass is the strategic link connecting Ladakh to Srinagar and the rest of India.

question: Which of the following is the highest mountain in Bhutan? SSC MTS 02/11/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Gangkhar Puensum (7,570 meters). Other Mountains of Bhutan : Kula Kangri (7538 m), Jomolhari. Bhutan : Capital - Thimphu, Currency - Ngultrum. Indian Drainage System

question: Trishulganga is a stream of the river: SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Gandak. It comprises two streams, namely Kaligandak and Trishulganga. It rises in the Nepal Himalayas between the Dhaulagiri and Mount Everest and drains the central part of Nepal. It enters the Ganga plain in Champaran district of Bihar and joins the Ganga at Sonpur near Patna.

question: Select the odd one from the following saltwater lakes on the basis of their formation? SSC MTS 09/10/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Sambhar lake: The largest inland saltwater lake in India situated in Rajasthan. Pulicat lake (Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu), Kolleru lake (Andhra Pradesh), and Chilika lake (Odisha) - are all coastal saltwater lakes, formed by the seawater entering the lake through creeks or rivers.

question: The Zaskar and the Nubra are tributaries of which river? SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Indus (Sindhu) originates from a glacier near Bokhar Chu in the Tibetan region at an altitude of 4,164 m in the Kailash Mountain range. Tributaries - Chenab River, Jhelum River, Ravi River, Satluj River, Beas River, Shyok River, Gilgit River, Hunza River, Swat River, Kunnar River, Kurram River, Gomal River, and Kabul River.

question: Which of the following rivers ﬂows north of the Tropic of Cancer in India? SSC MTS 30/10/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Yamuna. Originates - Yamunotri Glacier, Flows through the Himalayan foothills before entering the Indo-Gangetic Plain. Tributaries - Tons, Hindon, Chambal, Sind, Betwa, and Ken. The Yamuna River joins the Ganges River near Prayagraj (Allahabad). The Mahi River is the only river in India that crosses the Tropic of Cancer twice. Originates in the Vindhya Mountains in Madhya Pradesh, ﬂows through Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Gujarat, and drains into the Arabian Sea.

question: What is the salt measurement in hypersaline lagoons? SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: More than 100. Hypersaline lagoons are extreme environments with salt concentrations signiﬁcantly higher than typical seawater. While normal ocean salinity is around 35 parts per thousand (3.5%), hypersaline lagoons can have salt concentrations exceeding 100 parts per thousand (10%). These environments are typically found in arid regions with high evaporation rates and limited water input, such as the Dead Sea.

question: In which state of India is kund or Tanka used for water harvesting ? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Rajasthan. This region faces extreme arid conditions and low rainfall, so local communities have developed innovative systems to conserve and store water. Water harvesting structures in other States: Kere (large tanks) in Karnataka, Cheruvu in Andhra Pradesh, Bandharas and Tals in Maharashtra, Surangam in Kerala, Eris (tanks) in Tamil Nadu, Bhundis in Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh.

question: Which of the following is the transboundary river between India and Pakistan? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ravi. This river ﬂows through north-western India and eastern Pakistan. It, along with the Beas and Sutlej rivers, was allocated to India under the Indus Water Treaty. Indus River : This river originates in western Tibet, passes through Kashmir, and ﬂows into Pakistan before falling into the Arabian Sea. It, along with the Chenab and Jhelum rivers, was allocated to Pakistan under the Indus Water Treaty of 1960.

question: In which state of India was the Neeru-Meeru programme introduced for construction of water harvesting structures? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Andhra Pradesh. The Neeru-Meeru (Water and You) program was launched by the Water Conservation Mission (WCM), on May 1, 2000. It was a Water conservation and poverty alleviation initiative.

question: Identify a water-harvesting system found in Jaisalmer. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Khadins. ‘Rooftop rainwater harvesting’ was commonly practised to store drinking water, particularly in Rajasthan. In arid and semi-arid regions, agricultural ﬁelds were converted into rain fed storage structures that allowed the water to stand and moisten the soil like the ‘khadins’ in Jaisalmer and ‘Johads’ in other parts of Rajasthan. In hill and mountainous regions, people built diversion channels like the ‘guls’ or ‘kuls’ of the Western Himalayas for agriculture.

question: Which of the following rivers marks the eastern-most boundary of the Himalayas ? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Brahmaputra River ﬂows through the northeastern part of India, originating from the Angsi Glacier in Tibet and passing through Arunachal Pradesh before entering Assam. The Teesta River rises in the Pauhunri Mountain of the eastern Himalayas and ﬂows through the Indian states of Sikkim and West Bengal. The Satluj River originates in Raksas Tal near Mansarovar in Tibet. The Kali River ﬂows through the Uttara Kannada district of Karnataka.

question: Which of the following peninsular rivers falls into the Arabian Sea? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Sabarmati river. It is one of the major west-ﬂowing rivers in India. It originates from Aravalli hills. Mahanadi river: Origin - Sihawa (South of Amarkantak) near Raipur (Chhattisgarh). It ﬂows through Chhattisgarh and Odisha and drains into the Bay of Bengal.

question: In the ancient temple of Mahadev at Mahabaleshwar, the spout emerging from the mouth of a cow statue is the source of which river basin? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Krishna. It is the second largest east ﬂowing Peninsular river which rises near Mahabaleshwar in Sahyadri. Origin of rivers : Kaveri - originates at Talakaveri, which is located on the Brahmagiri range in the Kodagu (Coorg) district of Karnataka. Godavari - rises from Trimbakeshwar in the Nashik district of Maharashtra. Narmada - rises from Maikala range near Amarkantak in Madhya Pradesh.

question: Which of the following are west ﬂowing rivers? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Mahi and Sabarmati. Mahi River originates from Vindhyachal Hills, Madhya Pradesh and meets in Bay of Khambhat. Major West-ﬂowing rivers - Indus, Narmada, and Tapi. Major East-ﬂowing rivers: Ganga, Brahmaaputra, Mahanadi, Krishna, and Godavari. Major peninsular rivers - Mahanadi, Godavari, Krishna, Kaveri, Narmada, and Tapti.

question: Which of the following rivers is an east ﬂowing river? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Godavari river. It rises in the Nasik district of Maharashtra and discharges its water into the Bay of Bengal. It is 1,465 km long with a catchment area spreading over 3.13 lakh square kilometers. The Penganga, the Indravati, the Pranhita, and the Manjra are its principal tributaries. The Mahi (Origin, Northern slope of Vindhyas), Narmada (Origin, Amarkantak), and Tapi (Origin, Betul) rivers ﬂow westward, draining into the Arabian Sea.

question: ‘Bhagirathi’ and ‘Alaknanda’ rivers conﬂuence at: SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Devaprayag. The Five Prayags are sacred river conﬂuences in Uttarakhand. At Devaprayag, the Bhagirathi and Alaknanda rivers meet. At Rudraprayag, the Mandakini and Alaknanda rivers converge. At Nandaprayag, the Nandakini joins the Alaknanda. At Karnaprayag, the Pindar meets the Alaknanda, and at Vishnuprayag, the Dhauliganga merges with the Alaknanda.

question: Which state of India has the maximum number of large dams? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Maharashtra leads in large dams, followed by Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat. Major dams in Maharashtra include Jayakwadi, Koyna, and Radhanagari. India's ﬁrst dam, Kallanai, was built over 2,000 years ago. Notable post-independence dams include Hirakud (1957), Gandhisagar (1960), Bhakra-Nangal (1963), and Nagarjuna Sagar (1967).

question: In which group of states does the Luni River ﬂow? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Rajasthan and Gujarat. The Luni River begins near Pushkar valley in two branches called the Saraswati and the Sabarmati. These two branches merge at Govindgarh, and from there, the river ﬂows out of the Aravalli as the Luni. It continues westward until Telwara, then turns southwest to join the Rann of Kutch (Gujarat).

question: Which of the following is NOT a tributary of the Ganga? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Lohit is a tributary to the Brahmaputra River. Ganga’s Tributaries www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography include: Yamuna, Son, Gomti, Ghaghra, Gandak, and Kosi rivers.

question: The Aryans lived in the land known as ‘Sapta Sindhu’ (Land of the Seven Rivers). Which of the following was NOT a part of it? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Shipra. The Shipra (Kshipra), a 195 km tributary of the Chambal River in Madhya Pradesh, ﬂows across the Malwa Plateau, passing through Ujjain, Ratlam, and Mandsaur before joining the Chambal. The Sapta Sindhu, mentioned in Vedic literature, refers to the "Land of Seven Rivers" in Punjab, home to early Aryan settlements. The seven rivers include: Indus, Sutlej (Sutudri), Ravi (Parusni), Chenab (Asikni), Jhelum (Vitasta), Beas (Vipas), and Saraswati.

question: Which of the following rivers originates from the Himalayas? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ganga. Origin: Gangotri glacier near Gaumukh (3,900 m) in the Uttarkashi district of Uttarakhand. Here, it is known as the Bhagirathi. It cuts through the Central and the Lesser Himalayas in narrow gorges. At Devprayag, the Bhagirathi meets the Alaknanda; hereafter, it is known as the Ganga (length 2,525 km). Other river origin: Godavari - Brahmagiri hills; Tapi - Satpura range; Narmada - Maikal ranges.

question: Subansiri, Jia Bharali, Dhansiri and Puthimari are the major tributaries of which river? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Brahmaputra. The principal tributaries of the rivers are as follows: Godavari: Pravara, Purna, Manjra, Penganga, Wardha, Wainganga, Pranhita (the combined ﬂow of Wainganga, Penganga, and Wardha), Indravati, Maner, and Sabri. Mahanadi: Seonath, Hasdeo, Mand, and Ib join Mahanadi from the left, while Ong, Tel, and Jonk join from the right. Bhagirathi: Bhilangna River, Kedar Ganga, Jadh Ganga, etc.

question: On which river in India was the Somasila Dam built? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Pennar river. It originates in the Nandi Hills, Karnataka, and ﬂows through Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh before emptying into the Bay of Bengal. The Somasila dam is situated in the Nellore district (Andhra Pradesh). Famous dams and the rivers they are built on: Koyna Dam (Koyna River), Idukki Dam (Periyar River).

question: The Bist Doab Canal System and Makhu Canal System are associated with which state of India? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Punjab. Bist Doab lies between the Satluj and Beas rivers. The Makhu Canal System, built in 1950, is 92 km long and draws water from the Sutlej. Punjab's Doab systems include: Doab Chaj (Chenab and Jhelum), Doab Rachna (Ravi and Chenab), Doab Bari (Beas and Ravi, also called Majha), and Suj Doab (Satluj and Yamuna, part of the Malwa region).

question: The largest inland salt lake ‘Sambhar’ is located in the ______of India. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: north - west. Sambhar Salt Lake (located in Rajasthan) spans 230 square kilometers. It is a signiﬁcant depression in the Aravalli Range and is commonly referred to as the salt lake of Rajasthan. The lake receives water from six rivers: Mantha, Rupangarh, Khari, Khandela, Medtha and Samod.

question: Which of the following rivers is called ‘Singi Khamban’ in Tibet? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Indus. It enters Pakistan near Chilas in the Dardistan region. Brahmaputra: Originates from the Chemayungdung glacier in the Kailash range and is known as Tsangpo in Tibet. Sutlej: Originates near Mansarovar in Tibet, where it is called Langchen Khambab. River Kosi: Originates near Mount Everest and is known as the sorrow of Bihar due to frequent ﬂooding.

question: Match the pair correctly: National Waterways Stretch a) NW-1 1. Kakinada - Puducherry b) NW-2 2. Kottapuram- Kallam c) NW-3 3. Allahabad - Haldia d) NW-5 4. Sadiya- Dhubri 5. Talcher - Dhamra SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: a-3, b-4, c-2, d-5. NW-1 is the longest waterway in India, stretching 1,620 kilometers from Haldia to Allahabad. NW-69 is the smallest (5 km) waterway in India. It is part of the Manimuthar River in Tamil Nadu.

question: The Chilika Lake is located to the south of the ________ delta. SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Mahanadi. Chilika Lake, Asia’s largest and the world’s second-largest lagoon, spans Puri, Khurda, and Ganjam districts in Odisha. It is India's largest saltwater lake and the ﬁrst Ramsar wetland site (1981). Nalabana Island, a bird sanctuary, lies in the middle of Chilika Lake, while Satapada, where the lake meets the Bay of Bengal, is home to Irrawaddy dolphins.

question: Delhi ridge is the water divide between which of the following rivers? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Ganges and Indus. The uplift of the Potwar Plateau during the Pleistocene upheaval in the western Himalayas rises the Delhi ridge. The major water dividers of India: Vindya range: Divided the Ganga drainage basin and Narmada river valley. Satpuda range: Divided Narmada river and tapi river valley.

question: Which of the following pairs of Indian rivers is west ﬂowing? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Narmada and Tapi. Narmada River (Rewa River), the longest west-ﬂowing river, originates from the Maikal ranges and ﬂows through Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, and Maharashtra. The Tapi River, the second-largest west ﬂowing river, originates from Betul district in Madhya Pradesh and ﬂows parallel to the Narmada. Other important www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography west-ﬂowing rivers include Periyar, Bharathappuzha, Netravati, Sharavathi, and Mandovi.

question: Match the following dams with the rivers on which they are built. a. Hirakud Dam (i) Chambal river b. Nagarjuna Sagar Dam (ii) Narmada River c. Sardar Sarovar Dam (iii) Krishna River d. Tehri Dam (iv) Mahanadi river e. Rana Pratap Sagar dam (v) Bhagirathi river SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.correct_answer: A. a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-v, e-i
solution.explanation: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-v, e-i. The Hirakud Dam, one of the longest in the world, is located near Sambalpur District, Odisha. The Nagarjuna Sagar Dam, a masonry dam, spans the border between Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. The Sardar Sarovar Dam, a concrete gravity dam, is situated near Kevadiya in Gujarat's Narmada District. The Tehri Dam, a multi-purpose rock and earth-ﬁll embankment dam, is in New Tehri, Uttarakhand. The Rana Pratap Sagar Dam, a gravity masonry dam, stands 53.8 meters high in Rawatbhata, Rajasthan.

question: Which of the following rivers is joined by river Chambal from the south? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Yamuna. It rises from the Yamunotri Glacier in the Himalayas. It ﬂows parallel to the Ganga and as a right the bank tributary meets the Ganga at Allahabad. Its biggest tributary is Chambal River on the right. Other important tributaries include the Hindon, Sarda, and Giri rivers on the right and Betwa and Sindh on the left.

question: Choose the coasts that are running along the Arabian sea. a. Northern Circars, b. Malabar, c. Konkan, d. Coromandel SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Only b and c. The western coast, between the Western Ghats and the Arabian Sea, is a narrow plain with three sections: Konkan (Mumbai to Goa) in the north, Kannad Plain in the center, and Malabar Coast in the south. On the Bay of Bengal side, the plains are wide and level, called the Northern Circar in the north and the Coromandel Coast in the south.

question: Which river ﬂows into the Wular lake in the north and then into Baramulla? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Jhelum River originates from a spring at Verinag in the southeastern part of the Kashmir Valley. It ﬁrst ﬂows northward into Wular Lake, located in the northwestern part of the valley. After leaving Wular Lake, it changes direction, ﬂowing southwards. At Baramulla, the river enters a gorge in the hills, carving a steep-sided narrow passage through the Pir Panjal Range below Baramulla. Eventually, it merges with the Chenab River at Trimmu.

question: Which river originates from ‘Rakshastal north-western tip’ near Mansarovar ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Sutlej River enters India through the Shipki La Pass in the Kinnaur district of Himachal Pradesh. It is an east bank tributary of the Indus River, meeting the Indus at Mithankot in Pakistan. Also known as Shatadru in ancient times, the Satluj is the only Indus tributary originating from Tibet. The Bhakra-Nangal Dam is built across the Satluj, and the Indira Gandhi Canal also draws water from it.

question: In which of the following districts is Baira Siul Dam located ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Chamba. The Baira Siul hydroelectric plant is an operational hydroelectric power facility located in Chaurah, Himachal Pradesh. It is a type of Earthen / Gravity & Masonry dam. Length: 160m and Height: 53m. River: Baira + Bhaled + Siul / Ravi. Other dam of Himachal Pradesh and district: Pandoh Dam and Bassi Dam (Mandi), Kol Dam and Bhakra dam (Bilaspur), Karchham-Wangtoo Dam (Kinnaur), Chamera Dam (Chamba), Parbati Dam (mandi).

question: Choose the correct statement about the peninsular rivers. a. The Narmada rises in the Malwa plateau. b. The Godavari rises from the slopes of the Western Ghats near Nashik. c. The Mahanadi rises in the highlands of Chhattisgarh. d. The Krishna rises from a spring near Mahabaleshwar. SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.correct_answer: D. Only b, c and d
solution.explanation: Only b, c and d. The Narmada River rises from the Amarkantak Plateau in Anuppur district in Madhya Pradesh. The Peninsular drainage system : It is older than the Himalayan river. These rivers are characterised by ﬁxed course, absence of meanders and non-perennial ﬂow of water. Most of the major rivers (except Narmada and Tapi which ﬂow east to west) ﬂow from west to east. The Chambal, the Sind, the Betwa, the Ken, the Son, originating in the northern part of the Peninsula belong to the Ganga river system.

question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct about River Ganga ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)

options.B: River Ganga in India is more than
options.C: River Ganga and its river basin
options.D: The water level of River Ganga never

solution.correct_answer: D. The water level of River Ganga never
solution.explanation: The Ganga river depends on the rains brought by the southwesterly monsoon winds from July to October as well as on the ﬂow from melting Himalayan snow. The Wildlife Institute of India conducted a survey revealing that 49% of the Ganga River has high biodiversity.

question: In which district of Uttarakhand does the Ramganga river originate from the Doodhatoli ranges? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Pauri Garhwal. The Ramganga is a smaller river that begins near Gairsain in the Garhwal mountains. It changes direction to the southwest after crossing the Shiwalik and enters the plains of Uttar Pradesh near Najibabad. It eventually joins the Ganga near Kannauj. www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

question: Trishulganga is a stream of the river: SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Gandak. It comprises two streams, namely Kaligandak and Trishulganga. It rises in the Nepal Himalayas between the Dhaulagiri and Mount Everest.

question: The drainage basin of the Godavari river is present in which of the following states of India ? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Godavari River (Dakshin Ganga) - Second longest river in India after the Ganges River. Origin - Trimbakeshwar near Nashik in Maharashtra. It has the largest Peninsular River system and falls into the Bay of Bengal.

question: With which neighbouring country did India sign the Farakka Treaty in 1996 for sharing of the Ganga Waters and on augmenting its ﬂows? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Bangladesh. Farakka water -sharing treaty - It was signed by then PM H. D. Deve Gowda (India) and PM Sheikh Hasina Wajed (Bangladesh). India’s treaty with its Neighbours: Nepal Treaty - Mahakali treaty (1996), and Pakistan - Indus Waters Treaty (1960).

question: Identify the dam that is located in South India. SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Mettur dam: Built on Kaveri river and located at Mettur, Salem District (Tamil Nadu). Gandhi Sagar dam - Built on Chambal River and located in the Mandsaur district (Madhya Pradesh). Tilaiya dam - Constructed by Damodar Valley Corporation across Barakar River, in Koderma district (Jharkhand).

question: Which east-ﬂowing river basin covers the states of Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh and Orissa and has a Drainage area of 39,033 sq km ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Brahmani river (second largest river in Odisha): It is formed by the conﬂuence of the Shankh and Koel rivers, both join at Veda Vyasa near Rourkela (Odisha). Baitarani: It originates from Gonasika hills and drains into the Bay of Bengal. Nagavali (Langulya): It rises in the Eastern Ghats. Sarada: Originated from Kalapani in the Himalayas and ﬂows along Nepal's western border with India and joins Ghaghra River.

question: Which ports belong to the western coast of India ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

options.D: Kandla port, Haldia port, Kochi port

solution.correct_answer: A. Kandla port, Mormugao port, Kochi
solution.explanation: Ports in India: West Coast - Mumbai, Jawaharlal Nehru (Maharashtra), New Mangalore (Karnataka). East Coast - V. O. Chidambaranar formerly Tuticorin, Ennore, Chennai Port (Tamil Nadu), Paradip (Orissa), Kolkata, Haldia (West Bengal), Port Blair, Haddo (Andaman and Nicobar Islands).

question: The drainage system formed when rivers discharge their waters from all directions in a lake or depression, as in the case of Loktak Lake in Manipur, is called ________. SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Centripetal. Radial drainage pattern: When the rivers originate from a hill and ﬂow in all directions. Example - Narmada. Trellis Drainage Pattern: This pattern develops in folded topography where hard and soft rocks exist parallel to each other. Example - The rivers in the upper part of the Himalayan region Indus, Ganga. Dendritic Drainage Pattern : Most common form and resembles the branching pattern of tree roots. Example - The rivers of the northern plains, Indus, Ganga and Brahmaputra.

question: Dihang and Lohit are rivers in which of the following regions? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Arunachal Pradesh and Assam. Dihang River - The Brahmaputra rises in Tibet, where it is known as Tsangpo and crosses over into India in Arunachal Pradesh under the name of Dihang. Lohit River - It originates in eastern Tibet, in the Zayal Chu range and surges through Arunachal Pradesh for 200 km, before emptying into the Brahmaputra river in the plains of Assam.

question: The _______ port was developed after Independence to ease the volume of trade on the Mumbai port. SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Kandla (Deendayal port). It is located on the Gulf of Kutch (Gujarat). It was constructed in the 1950s as the chief seaport serving western India, after the partition of India from Pakistan left the Karachi port in Pakistan.

question: Which river basin originates from the Western Ghats range of Karnataka state and has many tributaries such as the Noyyal, Kabini, Arkavathi and Amaravati? SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Kaveri river basin falls in 3 States (Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Kerala) and a Union Territory (Puducherry). It originates in the foothills of Western Ghats at Talakaveri. Tributaries - Shimsha, Hemavati, Bhavani, Lokapavani.

question: The Jog Falls, one of the highest waterfalls in India is the cataract of which river? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Sharavati - It originates at a place called Ambutheertha in the Thirthahalli taluk (Karnataka). Tungabhadra River is formed by the conﬂuence of the Tunga River and the Bhadra River, The two rivers originate in Mudigere Taluk of Chikmagalur District (Karnataka).

question: With a stretch of about 724 km, which river is one of the most important rivers of peninsular India ? www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Tapi River - It ﬂows through the states of Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Gujarat. The river originates in the Satpura Mountains in Madhya Pradesh and ﬂows westwards before emptying into the Arabian Sea.

question: Which river originates from the southern part of Devarayanadurga hill in Tumkur district, and ﬂows for about 221 km before joining Kaveri? SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Shimsha River (a tributary of the river Kaveri). Shimsha has a waterfall at Shimshapura in Malavalli Taluk (Mandya district, Karnataka). Devarayanadurga is a small hill station located in the Indian state of Karnataka. Girna River - It originates near Kem Peak in western ghats of Maharashtra and is a tributary of Tapti river. Ghataprabha River - Right bank tributary of the Krishna River. Waghur River - It originates near Ajanta in the Aurangabad district of Maharashtra.

question: Which glacier is the source of river Gori Ganga which is an important tributary of river Kali? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Milam Glacier. Indian Rivers that Originate from Glaciers: Chenab - Bara-lacha la Glacier (Himachal Pradesh). Mandakini River - Chorabari Glacier (Uttarakhand). Lidder River - Kolahoi Glacier (Himalayas). Pushpawati - Tipra Glacier. Ram Ganga - Namik glacier.

question: Which of the following lakes is the longest in India? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Vembanad lake (Kerala) : Length 83.72 km and Width 14.48 km. It is connected to the Arabian Sea. The lake is known for its backwaters (a network of canals and waterways). Kanjia Lake - Odisha. Ansupa Lake - Odisha.

question: Which river from the following ﬂows through a rift valley? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Tapi. Rift valley : It is a lowland region that forms where Earth’s tectonic plates move apart. Famous rift valleys : Great Rift Valley (East Africa), East Rift Valley or Hualien - Taitung (Taiwan), Baikal Rift Valley (Southern Siberia).

question: Which tributary of the Indus River originates near the Rohtang Pass at an altitude of 4,000 meters above mean sea level ? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Beas. The ancient name of the river Beas was Vipasha. Tributaries of the Beas river : Parbati, Banganga, Tirthan, Suketi, Sainj, Gaj, Chakki and Uhaul.

question: Which is the biggest tributary of the upper Brahmaputra that originates in the Tibetan Himalayas and winds its way into India through Arunachal Pradesh ? SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Subansiri.
