question: Tropical cyclones originate over which of the following regions? SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Morning)

options.A: Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and the
options.C: Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and the

solution.correct_answer: A. Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and the
solution.explanation: A tropical cyclone is formed over warm ocean waters near the equator. The centre of a cyclone is very calm and clear with very low air pressure. The average speed is 120 kmph. They move from east to west under the inﬂuence of trade winds.

question: Which of the following statements regarding orographic rainfall is correct? SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024

options.A: It occurs mainly during summer and

solution.explanation: Orographic rainfall occurs when moist air hits a mountain and is forced to rise. As the air ascends, it cools, leading to condensation and saturation. The excess moisture then falls as precipitation on the windward slopes.

question: The climatic diversity of India is characterised by its distinctiveness, and one of the following factors does NOT contribute to it is ___________. SSC MTS 22/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: The latitudinal extent inﬂuences temperature and rainfall patterns due to variations in solar energy and atmospheric density. However, it is not a major factor contributing to India's www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography climatic diversity compared to longitudinal extent, topography, and vegetation.

question: Which state lies in the rain shadow region of the Arabian Sea branch of the southwest monsoon? SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Tamil Nadu. The Bay of Bengal monsoon branch strikes Myanmar and southeast Bangladesh, but the Arakan Hills deﬂect much of it towards India. It enters West Bengal and Bangladesh from the south - southeast, splitting into two branches. One moves westward along the Ganga plains to the Punjab plains, while the other ascends the Brahmaputra valley, causing rains in the northeast. A sub-branch hits Meghalaya's Khasi hills. The Tamil Nadu coast remains dry as it lies parallel to the Bay of Bengal monsoon branch and in the rain-shadow region of the Arabian Sea branch.

question: In which part of India does the hot wind ‘Loo’ blow? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: North and Northwestern. Loo - These are strong, gusty, hot, dry winds blowing during the day over the north and northwestern India. In West Bengal, similar storms are known as ‘Kaal Baisakhi’. They blow in the summer season. Other hot winds - Foehn (Europe), Chinook (USA), Santa Ana (USA), Sirocco (North Africa and South Europe), Harmattan (Guinea coast), Khamsin (Egypt).

question: The climate of a place is NOT affected by which of the following? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Type of soil. Climate refers to the long-term conditions of a speciﬁc region. The changes in climate within a region are inﬂuenced by its atmospheric and environmental conditions. The six major factors that inﬂuence the climate of a location are latitude, altitude, pressure, and wind systems, distance from the sea (continentality), ocean currents, and relief features.

question: Which region in India receives less rainfall in summer, but heavy rainfall in winter season due to the retreating north easterly winds? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Eastern coastal region stretches from West Bengal in the north to Tamil Nadu in the south and passes through Andhra Pradesh and Odisha. The retreating or North-East monsoon brings heavy rainfall to the Coromandel coast from October to December. This monsoon, blowing from land to sea, gathers moisture and causes rain, making it the primary rainy season for southeastern India, including Tamil Nadu. The Coromandel coast lies between Pulicat Lake and Kanyakumari.

question: Which is the colloquial term to describe the occurrence of pre-monsoon rains in India especially in parts of Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Mango showers. These are pre-monsoon rains that occur at the end of the summer season, helping the mangoes ripen; These are also called April rains.

question: The tropical cyclones in Australia are known as ________. SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: willy-willies. Tropical cyclones are intense low-pressure areas that form in the atmosphere between 30° N and 30° S latitudes. They can extend up to 1,000 km horizontally and 12–14 km vertically from the surface. Tropical cyclones rotate counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. Their names in different countries : Hurricanes - United States, Typhoons - China Sea and Paciﬁc Ocean, Cyclones - Indian Ocean.

question: What is the duration of monsoon in India? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 100-120 days. The monsoon season in India lasts from June to September. The southwest monsoon (summer monsoon) brings the majority of annual rainfall, blowing from the sea to land across the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal. In contrast, the northeast monsoon (winter monsoon) blows from land to sea.

question: Which of the following group of months is the coldest in North India? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: In December and January, temperatures decrease from south to north, with the Northern Plains averaging 10°C to 15°C, while Chennai on the eastern coast sees averages of 24°C to 25°C. Days are warm, and nights are cold during this period.

question: Which of the following parts of the mountain will receive the most rainfall from moisture-laden winds? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Windward side - The on-shore moisture laden winds are forced to rise after striking against the mountains and give heavy rainfall on the windward side. Leeward side - It receives little to no rainfall and is known as the rain shadow area. Orographic rainfall occurs when saturated air mass comes across a mountain.

question: Which theory describes the collective effects of changes in Earth's movements on its climate over thousands of years? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Milankovitch theory. Copernican heliocentrism, proposed by Copernicus in 1543, positions the Sun at the center, with Earth and other planets orbiting it. Plate tectonics is a scientiﬁc theory that explains how major landforms are created as a result of Earth's subterranean movements.

question: Which of the following groups of places in India has little differences in day and night temperatures? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Chennai and Thiruvananthapuram. Thar desert experiences the highest diurnal range of temperature. This is because of the fact that sand (found in ample quantity in this region) gains and loses heat very quickly. As a result of this phenomenon, there is a wide difference between day and night temperatures in this region. The day temperature may rise to 50°C and drop down to near 15°C the same night. There is no sea closer to this area and hence there is no moderating effect.

question: Which of the following statements about climate is INCORRECT? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Central Asia generally experiences stronger winters compared to India due to its continental location and lack of moderating inﬂuences like large bodies of water. The Climate of India is the tropical monsoon climate type with regional variations in temperature, precipitation, and amount of rainfall because of the large geographical area.

question: Western disturbances are responsible for: SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (2nd shift)

options.A: dusty storms in eastern coastal area

solution.correct_answer: D. rainfall during winters in north -
solution.explanation: The western cyclonic disturbances which enter the Indian subcontinent from the west and the northwest during the winter months, originate over the Mediterranean Sea and are brought into India by the westerly jet stream.

question: According to Koeppen's Scheme of classiﬁcation of climate, which of the following characteristics is associated with 'Group E' ? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. The average temperature for all
solution.explanation: Climatic Groups According to Koeppen: A - Tropical: Average temperature of the coldest month is 18° C or higher. B - Dry Climates: Potential evaporation exceeds precipitation. C - Warm Temperate: The average temperature of the coldest month of the (Mid-latitude) climates is higher than minus 3°C but below 18°C. D - Cold Snow Forest Climates: The average temperature of the coldest month is minus 3° C or below. H - High Land: Cold due to elevation.

question: El Nino is a climate pattern that describes the unusual warming of surface waters in which ocean? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Paciﬁc Ocean. El Nino is a complex weather system that occurs every 3-7 years, causing droughts, ﬂoods, and extreme weather globally. It involves warm ocean currents off Peru's coast in the Eastern Paciﬁc, affecting various regions, including India. El Nino is an extension of the warm equatorial current that temporarily replaces the cold Humboldt (Peruvian) Current, increasing water temperatures by 10°C.

question: In the context of local storms of hot weather season, Nor'Westers are: SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

options.A: the pre-monsoon showers that are a
options.C: the hot, dry and oppressing winds
options.D: a nearby wind that blows coffee

solution.correct_answer: B. the dreaded evening thunderstorms in
solution.explanation: Nor Westers : Their notorious nature can be understood from the local nomenclature of ‘Kalbaisakhi’, a calamity of the month of Baisakh. These showers are useful for tea, jute and rice cultivation. In Assam, these storms are known as “Bardoli Chheerha”. Some Famous Local Storms: Blossom Shower: Useful for coffee ﬂowers blooming in Kerala. Loo : Hot, dry and oppressing winds blowing in the Northern plains.

question: Which of the following States/Union Territories of India receives the highest average annual rainfall ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Meghalaya. The maximum rainfall of this season is received in the north-eastern part of the country. Mawsynram in the southern ranges of the Khasi Hills receives the highest average rainfall in the world. Mawsynram, the wettest place on the earth is also reputed for its stalagmite and stalactite caves. Rainfall in the Ganga valley decreases from the east to the west. Rajasthan and parts of Gujarat get scanty rainfall.

question: One term for the continuous movement of water through the lithosphere, atmosphere and hydrosphere is: SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: hydrological cycle. Components of the Hydrological Cycle : Evaporation - Water changes from liquid to gas, primarily from bodies of water.

question: Identify a type of season that is NOT a part of the four seasons of India. Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: The southeast monsoon season. Four main seasons can be identiﬁed in India : The hot weather season (March to May), The southwest monsoon season (June to September), The post - monsoon or retreating monsoon season (October to December), The cold weather season (January to February).

question: What is the name of the cold phase of the ENSO climate pattern that describes the unusual cooling of the surface waters of the region ? Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

solution.explanation: La Nina. In La Nina, the tropical Paciﬁc trade winds become very strong and an abnormal accumulation of cold water occurs in the central and eastern Paciﬁc Ocean. El Nino is a climate pattern that describes the unusual warming of surface waters in the eastern tropical Paciﬁc Ocean. El Nino is the “warm phase” of a larger phenomenon called the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO).

question: Sea ice helps determine Earth's climate. According to this, what percentage of the sunlight falling on sea ice is reﬂected back into space ? Higher Secondary 20/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: 80%. Sea ice reﬂects a signiﬁcant portion of sunlight, which is essential for regulating Earth’s temperature. As sea ice diminishes, more solar energy is absorbed by the ocean, resulting in higher temperatures. This change affects global climate patterns and contributes to the acceleration of climate change. Albedo is the percentage of solar radiation reﬂected by a given surface.

question: Who is best known for his testimony on climate change to congressional committees in the 1980s, which helped raise wider awareness of the global warming issue? Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: James Hansen. He is referred to as the “father of global warming” because of his early warnings about the phenomenon in the 1980s.

question: According to the Koppen climate classiﬁcation system, ‘Am’ is the code for which type of climate? Graduate Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: Tropical monsoon climate. Koeppen’s Classiﬁcation of Climatic Regions of India is based on mean annual and monthly temperature and precipitation data. He identiﬁed ﬁve major climatic groups: four based on temperature (A, C, D, E for humid climates) and one on precipitation (B for dry climates). These groups are further divided into types, indicated by small letters that describe seasonality: f (no dry season), m (monsoon), w (winter dry), and s (summer dry). Climatic Regions of India: Amw, As, Aw, BShw, BWhw, Cwg, Dfc, Et, E.

question: How many controls are there globally that inﬂuence the climate of a particular zone? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 6. There are six major controls of the climate of any place. They are: latitude, altitude, pressure and wind system, distance from the sea (continentality), ocean currents and relief features.

question: When was the Indian Meteorological Department, which collects data on temperature, rainfall, wind, etc., and makes weather forecasts, established by the Government of India? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 1875. Indian Meteorological Department - An agency of the Ministry of Earth Sciences of the Government of India. It is the principal agency responsible for meteorological observations, weather forecasting and seismology. Formed - 15 January 1875. Headquarters - New Delhi. Regional oﬃces - Chennai, Mumbai, Kolkata, Nagpur, Guwahati and New Delhi.

question: Choose the INCORRECT statement related to monsoon. SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)

options.A: The intensity and position of the

solution.explanation: Western Cyclonic Disturbances are weather phenomena of the winter months brought in by the westerly ﬂow from the Mediterranean region. They usually inﬂuence the weather of the north and north-western regions of India. It originates over the Mediterranean: The region which includes the Mediterranean Sea and seven Member States, either partially (France, Portugal, Italy, Spain) or completely (Greece, Malta, Cyprus).

question: Which winds blow across the Asian continent at latitudes north of the Himalayas roughly parallel to the Tibetan highlands ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Jet streams - A narrow belt of high altitude (above 12,000 m) westerly winds in the Troposphere. Their speed varies from about 110 km/h in summer to about 184 km/h in winter. The polar jet is located between the 50°-60° latitude lines in both the northern and southern hemispheres. The subtropical jet is located around the 30° latitude line.

question: What type of climate is found in North Western Europe, West Coast of North America, North of California, Southern Chile, South-eastern Australia and New Zealand? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Marine west coast climate - Under the Koppen Climate Classiﬁcation, it comes under Warm Temperate (Mid-Latitude) Climates (Group C) and is represented by ‘Cfb’.

question: Choose the INCORRECT statement out of the following. SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)

options.A: There is an increase in rainfall
options.B: Most parts of the country receive
options.D: Some parts like the Tamil Nadu’s

solution.correct_answer: A. There is an increase in rainfall
solution.explanation: Rainfall decreases from the east to the west in Northern India because there is a decrease in the moisture content of the winds. The monsoon approaches the Indian landmass in two branches: The Arabian Sea branch (The monsoon winds originating over the Arabian Sea) and the Bay of Bengal branch.

question: In which type of rainfall, winds www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography move out from a high-pressure area with wind direction clockwise in the northern hemisphere, and anti-clockwise in the southern hemisphere ? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Anticyclone - It is the center of high pressure, surrounded by closed isobars. Due to Coriolis force, blowing winds are deﬂected from their paths to the right in the Northern hemisphere (Clockwise) and left in the Southern hemisphere (Anti clockwise). Cyclones that develop in the mid and high latitudes, beyond the tropical regions, are referred to as middle latitude or extratropical cyclones.

question: According to the Koppen classiﬁcation, Which regions experience cold humid winters with short summers? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Arunachal Pradesh. Koeppen identiﬁed a close relationship between the distribution of vegetation and climate.

question: What is the usual term used to describe the climate of India ? SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Tropical monsoon. A monsoon is a seasonal change in the direction of the prevailing, or strongest, winds of a region. It always blows from cold to warm regions. The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) designates four oﬃcial seasons: Winter (December to early April); Summer or pre-monsoon (April to June); Monsoon or rainy (June to September) and Post-monsoon (October to December).

question: What is 'Mahawat' in India ? SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

options.A: Cold waves during the winter season
options.D: Hot and dry winds during the summer

solution.correct_answer: C. Cyclonic rainfall during the winter
solution.explanation: Mahawat is the total amount of rainfall in the cold weather season, that is the winter season which is caused by the western cyclonic disturbances in the north and north -western part of India.

question: The target for the ﬁrst commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol is to reduce emissions of greenhouse gasses by 5.2% from 1990 levels? SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: 6. Kyoto Protocol: It was adopted on 11 December 1997 and entered into force on 16 February 2005. It was adopted in Kyoto, Japan. It was the result of the Rio-1992 and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Kyoto Protocol cover emissions of the six main greenhouse gases Carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydroﬂuorocarbons (HFCs), perﬂuorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexaﬂuoride (SF6).

question: In the context of mapping climate data, what term refers to a line drawn through all points on a map that contain the same amount of cloud? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Isonephs. Isocheim - A line on a map connecting points having the same average temperature in winter. Isohel - A line on a map connecting points having the same duration of sunshine. Isochalaz - A line of constant frequency of hail storms.

question: According to Koeppen's Scheme, which type of climate is denoted by 'Cwg' in India? SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Monsoon with dry winter - It is mostly found in the Ganga Plain, eastern Rajasthan, Assam, and the Malwa Plateau. Amw (Monsoon type with a short dry winter season): This climate is found in the western coastal region, south of Mumbai.

question: Which of the following is incorrectly matched? SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Montane climate - Found in Assam, Nagaland, Mizoram, Meghalaya, Manipur, Arunachal Pradesh, Higher hills of Tamil Nadu.

question: The centre of a cyclone is a calm area. It is called the_______of the storm. SSC CGL 24/07/2023( 4th shift)

solution.explanation: Eye. The eye of a storm is usually circular and typically 25-40 miles in diameter. It is surrounded by an eyewall, where the most severe weather of a cyclone occurs.

question: What would happen if the difference in pressure in Tahiti was negative? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.correct_answer: C. Below average and late monsoon
solution.explanation: The difference in pressure over Tahiti (Paciﬁc Ocean) and Darwin in Northern Australia (Indian Ocean) is computed to predict the intensity of the monsoons. Factors Affecting Monsoon - The shift of the position of Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ); The presence of the high-pressure area, east of Madagascar; Heating of The Tibetan plateau in summers; The movement of the jet streams; Southern Oscillation (SO) - Change of pressure between south Paciﬁc Ocean and eastern Indian Ocean.

question: What type of climate occurs along the west coast of continents in subtropical latitudes between 30°-40° latitudes, covering Central California, Central Chile along the coast in South East and South Western Australia? Matric Level 28/06/2023 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Mediterranean climate: Clear skies and high temperatures; hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters. The climate is not extreme because of cooling from water bodies. This unique seasonal pattern makes it ideal for growing crops like olives, grapes, and www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography citrus fruits.

question: What is the average temperature usually in the hills of the western ghats? Matric Level 30/06/2023 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: Below 25°C. Western Ghats - These are also known as the Sahyadri Hills. It covers six states - Gujarat, Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and Kerala.

question: Which winds are also known by the name of 'Roaring Forties' ? SSC MTS 11/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Westerly Wind. The polar easterlies are one of the ﬁve primary wind zones, known as wind belts, that make up our atmosphere's circulatory system. Polar winds begin near the North and South Poles. The trade winds are air currents closer to Earth's surface that blow from east to west near the equator.

question: Which among the following wind is associated with extreme cold and dryness? SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Polar Easterlies. They emanate from the polar highs, areas of high pressure around the North and South Poles. They ﬂow to low-pressure areas in sub-polar regions. Easterlies (blow from the east) - It is the name of the permanent winds that come from the direction of their origin. Monsoon Winds - They are caused when the air over land gets heated and rises, causing winds to blow from the ocean toward land. Westerlies - Prevailing winds from the west toward the east in the middle latitudes.

question: The summer months experience __________ in the northern part of India. SSC MTS 15/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Falling air pressure. An elongated low-pressure area develops in the region extending from the Thar Desert in the northwest to Patna and Chotanagpur plateau in the east and southeast towards the end of May. Circulation of air begins to set in around this trough. InterTropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) - Low pressure region around which the southeast trade winds and the northeast trade winds converge.

question: The day to day condition of the atmosphere at a place with respect to the temperature, humidity, rainfall, wind speed etc. is called _______ at that place. SSC MTS 16/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Weather. Climate - It is the long-term average of weather conditions, including temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind patterns, and other atmospheric elements, in a particular region over an extended period, typically 30 years or more.

question: Which of the following pressure belts is known as the horse latitude? SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Subtropical high pressure belts (Horse latitude) extend 30° N and 30° S. It is formed because the warm air rising from the equator moves towards the tropics in both hemispheres. Equatorial Low - Pressure belt extends from 0 to 5° North and South. The subpolar low pressure belt extends around latitudes 60° to 70° North and South. High Pressure belts are located at 70°- 90° North and South latitudes. There are majorly seven Pressure Belts on the surface of Earth i.e., the Equatorial Low, two Subtropical Highs, two Subpolar Lows, and two Polar Highs.

question: When the grains of sand are very ﬁne and light , the wind can carry it over a very long distance . When such sand is deposited in large areas, it is called_____. SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Loess. It is a clastic, predominantly silt-sized sediment that is formed by the accumulation of wind - blown dust.

question: Consider the following statements about the main reasons for the excessive cold in north India during the cold weather season and identify which of the statements are correct. 1. States like Punjab, Haryana and Rajasthan, being far away from the moderating inﬂuence of sea, experience continental climate. 2. The snowfall in the nearby Himalayan ranges creates a cold wave situation. 3. Around February, the cold winds coming from the Caspian Sea and Turkmenistan bring a cold wave along with frost and fog over the northwestern parts of India. SSC CGL Tier II 07/03/2023

solution.explanation: 1, 2 and 3. Coastal areas have moderate temperatures because the land absorbs and radiates heat much faster than sea. So, during the day cool air from the sea rushes towards the land and during the night cool air from the land rushes towards the sea.

question: Low annual range of temperature and high annual rainfall are characteristics of a _________. SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Tropical Humid Climate: Low range of temperature, Rainfall exceeds evapotranspiration for at least 270 days in a year, between Tropic of Cancer and Capricorn.

question: Which of the following codes signify the Cold Climate with Dry Winters according to Koeppen? SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Dw. Koeppen recognised six major climatic groups based on seasonal precipitation and temperature patterns. The six main groups are A (tropical), B (arid), C (temperate), D (continental), E (polar) and H (highland).

question: The cold snow forest climate is found largely in the continental region in the Northern Hemisphere between _______ northern latitudes in Europe, Asia and North America SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 40°-70°. India has a tropical climate because of the Himalayan mountain.

question: In early November, the low Pressure conditions shift over the Bay of Bengal. This transfer is related to cyclonic low pressure, which originates over ________. SSC MTS 13/07/2022 (Morning) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

solution.explanation: Andaman Sea (Burma sea in Thai) is a body of water to the southeast of the Bay of Bengal, south of Myanmar, west of Thailand and east of the Andaman Islands; it is a part of the Indian Ocean.

question: Which climate zone has an average temperature of over 64°F (18°C) throughout the year and more than 59 inches of rainfall each year? SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Tropical Zone. The tropics are regions of the Earth that lie roughly in the middle of the globe. The temperature remains high throughout the year. There is no marked winter season.

question: What type of climate do the two island regions of India, Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands experience? SSC CHSL 06/06/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Tropical warm climates with average temperatures ranging between 27° C - 32° C. Lakshadweep (an archipelago of 36 islands in the Arabian Sea). Hot semi-arid climate - Thar Desert.

question: What type of precipitation is common at the equatorial depression in the Congo Basin, the Amazon Basin, and the islands of South-east Asia? SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Conventional precipitation occurs when the energy of the sun (or insolation) heats the earth's surface and causes water to evaporate, changing to water vapor. Most of India's rainfall is conventional. It is prevalent in equatorial regions. Orographic precipitation occurs when a topographic barrier like a mountain blocks the path of a movement of air horizontally. Frontal precipitation occurs along the zone of contact between a warm and cool air mass.

question: ___is concerned with constructing records of past climates and climatic events by analysis of tree growth characteristics, especially growth rings. SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Dendroclimatology. Bioclimatology (biometeorology) is the study of the relationships between climate (weather) and living organisms. Historical climatology is the study of historical changes in climate and their effect on civilization from the emergence of hominids to the present day. Geo climatology is the study of climate which deﬁnes how it changes over time. Industries

question: Select the INCORRECT statement from the following. SSC MTS 21/10/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.A: The development of the cotton textile
options.B: Cotton clothes made in England had
options.C: The Sale and Devang communities of
options.D: The ﬁrst cotton textile mill in India

solution.correct_answer: B. Cotton clothes made in England had
solution.explanation: By the beginning of the 20th century, India was not competing in European and American markets because British policies had already eliminated Indian textile exports to these regions by the 19th century. The decline of Indian textiles in international markets occurred much earlier, during the late 18th and 19th centuries, following the Industrial Revolution in Britain.

question: Identify the oldest iron and steel company of India from the following options. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Tata Iron and Steel Company (TISCO): Founded by Jamsetji Tata and Dorabji Tata in 1907, It is located in Jamshedpur (Jharkhand). Visvesvaraya Iron and Steel Plant: Founded in 1923, this plant is situated in Bhadravathi (Karnataka), and specializes in the production of pig iron and steel. Indian Iron and Steel Company (IISCO): Established in 1918, IISCO is an integrated steel plant located in Burnpur (West Bengal) and is part of Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL).

question: Identify the group of districts that are NOT an example of industrial districts of India. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Alwar and Bhiwani. Cuttack (Odisha) is known for textile and handicraft industries, especially the silver ﬁligree (Tarakasi) work. Kota (Rajasthan) is famous for its engineering and chemical industries. Kanpur is a signiﬁcant industrial hub, historically known for its leather and textile industries. It is sometimes called the "Manchester of the East." Agra is widely known for its tourism, but it also has industries related to leather goods, footwear, and marble stone carving. Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh) is known for ordnance factories, defense-related industries, and manufacturing units. Bhopal (Madhya Pradesh) is a major industrial center with industries like electrical goods, chemicals, and the famous Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited (BHEL).

question: Which of the following is a public sector industry ? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: BHEL (Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited) was established in 1964 and is headquartered in New Delhi. Reliance Industries Limited is an Indian multinational company based in Mumbai, Maharashtra. It was founded by Dhirubhai Ambani. The Tata Group is one of India's oldest and largest business conglomerates. It was founded in 1868 by Jamsetji Tata. The Adani Group is an Indian multinational conglomerate based in Ahmedabad, Gujarat. It was founded in 1988 by Gautam Adani.

question: Which of the following is an example of a major industrial region of India? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Chota Nagpur region. India has several industrial regions like Mumbai- Pune cluster, Bangalore-Tamil www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography Nadu region, Hugli region, Ahmedabad -Baroda region, Chottanagpur industrial belt, Vishakhapatnam-Guntur belt, Gurgaon -Delhi-Meerut region and the Kollam-Thiruvanathapuram industrial cluster.

question: Where was the ﬁrst successful textile mill established in India? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Mumbai. The ﬁrst successful textile mill in India was the Bombay Spinning and Weaving Company, established in 1854 in Bombay (now Mumbai) by Cowasjee Nanabhoy Davar, a Parsi businessman and banker. Located in Tardeo, Bombay, it began production in 1856.

question: Where is the oldest centre of lace work located in Gujarat? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Jamnagar. Crafts Centers of Gujarat : Kutch - Known for its rich tradition in embroidery and textile crafts. Surat - It is an important silk weaving center of India and is famous for silk brocades. Rajkot - It is popular for traditional and folk silver jewelry. Palitana - Known for making bronze sculptures. Ahmedabad (Manchester of India) - Famous for cotton textile works. The ﬁrst cotton textile mill was started in 1861.

question: There is a cable manufacturing facility at HCL in Rupnarainpur. It belongs to which state? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: West Bengal. West Bengal along with their notable industries: Durgapur (Iron and Steel), Kharagpur (Chemicals), Haldia (petrochemicals), Darjeeling (tea), Chittaranjan (Electric locomotives), Asansol (Coal, Iron and Steel), Kalyani (Heavy Engineering), Rishra (Textiles).

question: According to the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion, which of the following is NOT a core industry ? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Jute. The eight core industries are- Coal, Crude oil, Natural Gas, Petroleum reﬁnery products, Fertilizer, Cement, Steel, and Electricity generation.

question: Select the INCORRECT pair of the location of the reﬁnery and its state from the following SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Tatipaka Reﬁnery - Telangana. Tatipaka Oil Reﬁnery is located in the East Godavari district in Andhra Pradesh. It was set up on 3rd September 2001. Some list of oil reﬁneries: Vadinar Reﬁnery (Gujarat), Kochi Reﬁnery (Kerala), Mangalore Reﬁnery (Karnataka), Paradip Reﬁnery (Odisha), Barauni Reﬁnery (Barauni in Bihar).

question: Which group of states was concentrated in the cotton production in the early years to develop textile industry? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Maharashtra and Gujarat. Cotton is a tropical crop and it is raised in India as a Kharif crop. Climatic condition - Temperatures between 21 degrees Celsius and 30 degrees Celsius. It grows best in Black soil. India grows both short staple (Indian) cotton as well as long staple (American) cotton called ‘narma’ in north-western parts of the country.

question: Where was the ﬁrst cement plant located in India in the year 1904 ? Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Chennai. South India Industries Limited in Madras, made an initiative to manufacture Portland cement. India entered into the Cement Era in 1914, when the Indian Cement Company Ltd. started manufacturing Cement in Porbandar in Gujarat.

question: Which group of oilﬁelds among the following is located in Assam? Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Digboi and Naharkatiya. Digboi Oilﬁeld : One of the oldest oil ﬁelds in Asia, discovered in 1867, and home to Asia's oldest oil reﬁnery (Established in 1901). It is located in Tinsukia district, Assam. Naharkatiya Oilﬁeld : Discovered in 1953, with oil production starting in 1954. It is located in Dibrugarh district, Assam. Other Oil Reﬁneries in Assam - Noonmati Reﬁnery, Numaligarh Reﬁnery, and Bongaigaon Reﬁnery. Kosamba, Lunej, Mehsana, Nawagam, Ankleshwar and Kalol are oil-producing regions located in Gujarat.

question: Which of the following cities is called the Silicon Valley of India due to its prominence in the IT industry ? Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: BengaluruI. Nicknames of Indian Cities: Hyderabad - City of Pearls; Gurugram - Millennium City; Korba - Power Hub of India; Jamshedpur - Steel Capital of India; Nalanda - The Land of Knowledge; Guntur - Land of Chillies; Kashmir - Switzerland of India; Pondicherry - Paris of the East; Coimbatore - Manchester of South India; Chennai - Detroit of Asia.

question: Which of the following is the only vertically-integrated, primary copper producer in India ? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Hindustan Copper Limited. It is a public sector undertaking under the Ministry of Mines. The company was incorporated on 9th November 1967, under the Companies Act, 1956. Headquarters - Kolkata.

question: At which of the following places was the shipbuilding industry started in 1941? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Visakhapatnam. Hindustan Shipyard Limited (Visakhapatnam): It was set up by Scindia Steam Navigation Company and the ﬁrst ship was launched in 1948. It was taken over by the Government in 1952 and was renamed as Hindustan Shipyard Ltd. In 1962, the shipyard became a central public sector enterprise. Cochin Shipyard Limited (Kochi) - Incorporated in 1972 as a www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography company fully owned by the Government.

question: The Kolar region of Karnataka is famous for which mineral from the following ? SSC MTS 14/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Gold. Kolar - Golden City of India. It is popularly known as the land of Silk, Milk, Mango, Gold. Other Gold mines - Hutti Gold Mines (Karnataka), Kolar Gold Fields (Karnataka), Lava Gold Mines (Jharkhand), Sonbhadra Mine (Uttar Pradesh), Parasi (Jharkhand), Dadam (Haryana).

question: Which state in India has the highest number of aluminium smelting plants? SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Odisha. Aluminum smelting plants - Korba, Alupuram, Renukoot, Mettur, Hirakud, Angul, Jharsuguda and Faridabad. Aluminium Companies in India - Hindustan Aluminium Company (Mumbai, Maharashtra), Vedanta Limited (Jharsuguda, Odisha), Sacheta Metals (Mumbai, Maharashtra).

question: Which of the following industries is its own major consumer in India? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Chemical. India is the 6th largest producer of chemicals in the world and 3rd in Asia. Also the fourth-largest producer of agrochemicals after the United States, Japan and China.

question: Which city in India is known as the ‘Detroit of India’ due to its automobile industry? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Chennai - It is contributing more than 40% of the country's auto parts and vehicles. The World's major automotive giants that operate in Chennai are TVS, Ashok Leyland, Royal Enﬁeld, TI Cycle, TAFE, Hyundai, Mitsubishi etc.

question: The Kudremukh Mines are located in which of the following states? SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Karnataka. Kudremukh Mines is an iron ore mine located in the Bellary, Chitradurga, Chikkamagaluru, Tumkur belt. Other Iron ore mines : Chhattisgarh - Rowghat Mines, Bailadila. Odisha - Balda Block, Joda East, Gorumahisani, Jajang Rungta. Madhya Pradesh - Agaria Iron Ore mine.

question: In which of the following regions in India are there high-grade iron ore deposits? SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Northern Odisha. The iron ore mines are located near the coal ﬁelds in the northeastern plateau region. Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Karnataka, Goa, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, and Tamil Nadu account for approximately 95% of total iron ore reserves. Iron Ore and Percentage of iron : Magnetite - 72 %, Hematite - 60-70 %, Limonite - 40 to 60%, Siderite - 48 %.

question: Which is the ﬁrst integrated steel plant in the public sector in India? SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Rourkela Steel Plant (Odisha - 1959). Established with the help of West German Industrial Corporations. Steel plants built in India during the Second Five Year Plan (FYP): Durgapur Steel Plant (West Bengal - Britain Cooperation), Bhilai Steel Plant (Chattisgarh - USSR Cooperation).

question: Which is the oldest aluminium reﬁnery plant in India? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: The Muri Alumina Plant - Situated near Chota Muri at Swarnarekha River in Ranchi (Jharkhand). It was commissioned in 1948. Its capacity is 450 Kilo tonne per annum (present). The Mettur Plant, Tamil Nadu. Damanjodi - Located in the Koraput district (Odisha), famous for discovery of bauxite mines and setting up of NALCO (National Aluminium Company Limited).

question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a minor industrial region of India? Matric Level 28/06/2023 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Hugli region. Minor Industrial regions : Jaipur- Ajmer, Indore- Dewas- Ujjain, Saharanpur-Muzaffarnagar- Bijnor, Kolhapur- South Kannada, Middle Malabar, Adilabad - Nizamabad, Prayag- Varanasi- Mirzapur, Bhojpur- Munger, Bilaspur- Korba, Brahmaputra valley. Major Industrial Regions of India: Kolkata - Hugli, Mumbai - Pune Belt, Bengaluru - Tamil Nadu Belt, Kollam - Thiruvananthapuram Belt, Visakhapatnam - Guntur Belt, Chotanagpur Plateau Belt, Ahmedabad - Vadodara Belt, Gurugram - Delhi - Meerut Belt.

question: Match the industrial plant with its location. Name of industrial Plant Related Location 1. BALCO

solution.explanation: BALCO (Bharat Aluminium Company Limited, 1965) has two working units, one in Korba (Chattisgarh) and one in Bidhanbag (West Bengal). ICF (Integral Coach Factory, 1955) is located in Perambur, Chennai, Tamil Nad.

question: In the beginning of the 19th century cotton mills in India were mostly located in which of the following states? SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Maharashtra. The ﬁrst cotton mill in India was set up as a spinning mill in Bombay in 1854. By 1900, over 84 mills (mostly by Parsi and Gujarati businessmen) started operating there.

question: With respect to value addition in the textile industry, knitting is followed by which procedure? SSC MTS 25/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Dyeing and ﬁnishing. In the textile industry, the process begins with ﬁber production, followed by spinning to create yarn, and then knitting or weaving to form fabric. Next comes dyeing, printing, and ﬁnishing to enhance the fabric, and ﬁnally, garment manufacturing, involving cutting and sewing. Thus, the step following knitting is dyeing and ﬁnishing.

question: Which of the following is dark reddish coloured stone used as raw material in aluminum smelting? SSC MTS 25/07/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Bauxite.

question: The Paithani saree weaving industry is in which state? SSC MTS 06/10/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Maharashtra. They are woven by hand. They are made from very ﬁne mulberry silk.

question: Imphal valley of Manipur is an important center of ________ craft. SSC MTS 07/10/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Kauna. Godna (Chattisgarh), Butta (Andhra Pradesh), and Miri Jims (Assam).

question: Which is the second most important metallurgical industry in India? SSC MTS 07/10/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Aluminium (after the iron and steel industry). It is light, resistant to corrosion, a good conductor of heat, malleable, and becomes strong when it is mixed with other metals. It is used to manufacture aircraft, utensils, and wires. Biosphere Reserves

question: Match the following. 1. Ranthambore National Park
In which state is Kawal Wildlife Sanctuary located ? SSC MTS 01/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Telangana. Kawal Tiger Reserve is located at Adilabad district in Telangana. It was declared a wildlife sanctuary in 1965 and later became part of the Kawal Tiger Reserve under Project Tiger in 2012. Other wildlife sanctuaries in Telangana - Pranahita wildlife sanctuary, Shivaram wildlife Sanctuary, Nagarjuna Sagar-Srisailam Tiger Reserve, Kinnerasani, and Manjira Wildlife Sanctuary.

question: The Betul, Hoshangabad and Chhindwara districts of Madhya Pradesh is a part of which of the following Biosphere Reserves? SSC MTS 18/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Pachmarhi Biosphere Reserve is recognized for its rich biodiversity and has been designated as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve in 2009. The Satpura mountain ranges across India from west to east and Pachmarhi lies directly in its centre. It comprises three protection sites: the Bori Sanctuary, Satpura National Park and Pachmarhi Sanctuary. Other Biosphere Reserve: Manas (Assam), Seshachalam (Andhra Pradesh), Agasthyamalai (Kerala and Tamil Nadu).

question: As of the June 2021, how many biosphere reserves are established in India? SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: 18. The Government of India started the Biosphere Reserve scheme in 1986. This is guided by the UNESCO MAB programme, as India is a signatory to the landscape approach supported by MAB. The Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve was the ﬁrst and Oldest biosphere reserve in India established in 1986.

question: Which national park in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands is home to species like Megapode, crab-eating Macaque, Nicobar Pigeon, and Giant Robber Crab? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Campbell Bay National Park, established in 1992, spans 426.23 square km and is part of the Great Nicobar Biosphere Reserve. Other notable parks include Raimona National Park in Assam (famous for elephants and tigers), Mouling National Park in Arunachal Pradesh (known for temperate forests and Himalayan wildlife), and Papikonda National Park in Andhra Pradesh (noted for Eastern Ghats biodiversity).

question: In which state of India is Tadoba National Park located? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Maharashtra. Tadoba National Park is located in the Chandrapur District. In 1955, it was given the designation of a National Park. Other National Parks of Maharashtra are Chandoli National Park, Navegaon National Park, Gugamal National Park, Sanjay Gandhi National Park.

question: In which state is the Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve located? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Uttarakhand. Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve included in UNESCO World Heritage site in 1988. Some biosphere reserves in India: Cold Desert (Himachal Pradesh), Khangchendzonga (Sikkim), Dihang - Dibang (Arunachal Pradesh), Manas (Assam), Dibru - Saikhowa (Assam), Nokrek (Meghalaya), Panna (Madhya Pradesh), Pachmarhi (Madhya Pradesh).

question: Select the natural habitat of the Asiatic Lion from the following. SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Gir forest. Asiatic lions are an endangered species and their availability is restricted only to the Gir National Park situated in Gujarat. India is the only country in the world to have both tigers and lions. Tigers are found in the forests of Madhya Pradesh, the Sundarbans of West Bengal. Number of Lions in India - 674. The ﬁrst tiger reserve in India was established in 1973 (Project Tiger).

options.B: Both I and III are correct

question: Which biosphere of Southern Andhra Pradesh is home to many endemic species including the famous Red Sanders and Slender Loris? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Seshachalam. It is a Biosphere Reserve situated in the Seshachalam Hill ranges of the Eastern Ghats in southern Andhra Pradesh, covering a total area of 4755.9 km². Seshachalam SLBR was designated in 2011. It is known for its large reserves of Red Sandalwood.

question: The Keoladeo National Park is located in the state of _______. Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: Rajasthan. Keoladeo National Park in Bharatpur district was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985. States and National Parks: Rajasthan - Ranthambhore, Sariska. Gujarat - Gir, Marine. Odisha - Simlipal. Madhya Pradesh - Bandhavgarh, Fossil, Madhav, Sanjay-Dubri.

question: Correctly match the following. States Bio-reserve 1. Assam a. Pachmarhi 2. Madhya Pradesh b. Nokrek 3. Odisha c. Manas 4. Meghalaya d. Similipa SSC CHSL Tier II 02/11/2023

Match the following. i) Gir National Park a) Rhinos ii) Rajaji National Park b) Siberian cranes iii) Keoladeo NationalPark c) Lions iv) Kaziranga National Park d) Elephants SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)

options.A: i-d, ii-b, iii-c, iv-a (b) i-d, ii-c, iii-a, iv-b
options.C: i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a (d) i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d

solution.correct_answer: C. i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a (d) i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
