Jim Corbett National Park (Uttarakhand) - Tiger; Sundarban National Park (West Bengal) - Bengal tiger; Dudhwa National Park (Uttar Pradesh) - Swamp deer and Tiger; Silent Valley National Park (Kerala) - Lion Tailed Macaque; Orang National Park (Assam) - One Horned Rhinoceros and the Royal Bengal Tiger.

question: Match the wildlife sanctuaries in column A with their corresponding states in column B. Column A (Wildlife Sanctuaries) Column B (States) 1. Tansa a. Tamil Nadu 2. Guindy b. Maharashtra 3. Orchha c. Madhya Pradesh 4. Kaziranga d. Assam SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
Which of the following is declared as a Wild Ass Sanctuary? SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Rann of Kachchh (Gujarat). It is the only home to wild ass in India. The sanctuary was set up in 1972.

question: Which of the following is the closest wild relative of domestic cattle protected in some of the famous national parks of India like Nagarhole and Bandipur? SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Gaur. First population estimation exercise of the Indian Gaur (Bison) was carried out in the Nilgiris Forest Division (Tamil Nadu).

question: In which Biosphere Reserve is the largest endangered marine mammal Dugong and sea turtles also found? SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 3rd shift)

solution.correct_answer: D. Gulf of Mannar Biosphere Reserve
solution.explanation: Gulf of Mannar Biosphere Reserve (Tamil Nadu, India’s ﬁrst marine biosphere reserve). Biosphere Reserves- Seshachalam (Andhra Pradesh), Khangchendzonga (Sikkim), Pachmarhi (Madhya Pradesh).

question: In which state is Gorumara National Park located? SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: West Bengal. Gorumara National Park was established in 1994. It is primarily known for its population of Indian rhinoceros. Other National Parks : West Bengal - Jaldapara, Sunderban, Singalila, Neora. Assam - Kaziranga, Nameri, Manas. Uttarakhand - Jim Corbett, Rajaji, Gangotri. Bihar - Valmiki. Rajasthan - Ranthambore, Keoladeo. Madhya Pradesh - Kanha, Van Vihar, Satpura.

question: The famous Nelapattu Bird Sanctuary is located in which of the following states? SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Andhra Pradesh. Nelapattu Bird Sanctuary - It is an important breeding site for spot-billed pelicans (Pelecanus philippensis). Other bird sanctuaries in Andhra Pradesh - Kolleru, Uppalapadu, Telineelapuram and Telukunchi. Tamil Nadu - Karikili Birds Sanctuary, Chitrangudi. Karnataka - Ranganathittu, Attiveri. Madhya Pradesh - Ghatigaon, Karera Bustard Sanctuary.

question: Which country is the only country in the world to have both tigers and lions? SSC MTS 16/06/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: India. The natural habitat of the Indian lion is the Gir forest in Gujarat. Tigers are found in the forests of Madhya Pradesh, the Sundarbans of West Bengal. Number of Lions in India - 674. In 2023, the tiger population in India was recorded at 3682.

question: The Eld's deer subspecies, which is classiﬁed as endangered in the IUCN Red List, is found only in the: SSC CHSL 26/05/2022(Afternoon)

solution.correct_answer: C. Keibul Lamjao National Park in
solution.explanation: Keibul Lamjao National Park in Manipur. IUCN Headquarter is at Gland, Switzerland. The 7 categories of the IUCN Red List are Data Deﬁcient (DD), Least Concern (LC), Near Threatened (NT), Vulnerable (VU), Endangered (EN), Critically Endangered (CR), Extinct In The Wild (EW), Extinct (EX).

question: The Buxa Tiger Reserve in West Bengal is threatened by the ongoing: SSC MTS 05/10/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Dolomite mining. Deforestation and large-scale developmental projects are the main reasons for the depletion of the Buxa Tiger Reserve.

question: In which of the following states is the Srivilliputhur Elephant Reserve located? SSC MTS 20/10/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Tamil Nadu. There are 33 Elephant Reserves in India. The very ﬁrst elephant reserve or elephant sanctuary was the Singhbhum Elephant Reserve of Jharkhand.

question: Baghmara Pitcher Plant Sanctuary is located in which of the following states? SSC CGL 13/08/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Meghalaya (South Garo Hills District). The sanctuary is named after a rare insectivorous Pitcher Plant that is endemic to this region only.

question: Laokhowa Wildlife Sanctuary lies on the southern bank of which river in the northeastern states of India ? SSC CHSL 13/04/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Brahmaputra. Laokhowa Wildlife Sanctuary is protected area located in the state of Assam. This wildlife sanctuary covers 70.13 km2, on the south bank of the Brahmaputra River in Nagaon district.

question: In which of the following Indian states is the Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary located? SSC CHSL 15/04/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Chhattisgarh (Balodabazar district). It was established in 1976 under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. The Jonk River ﬂows through the sanctuary, which is a tributary of the Mahanadi river.

question: In which of the following states is Kali Tiger Reserve located ? SSC CHSL 16/04/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Karnataka. Kali Tiger Reserve is a protected area and tiger reserve in Uttara Kannada district, in Karnataka. The park is a habitat of Bengal tigers, black panthers, and Indian elephants, amongst other distinctive fauna. The Kali River ﬂows through the whole tiger reserve.

question: Peppara Wildlife Sanctuary is situated in which of the following states ? SSC CHSL 16/04/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Kerala. Other Wildlife Sanctuaries in Kerala : Eravikulam, Periyar, Shendurney, Chinnar, Parambikulam, Idukki, Wayanad, Thattekad.

question: Dandeli Wildlife Sanctuary is located in which of the following states? SSC CHSL 05/08/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Karnataka.

question: The wetland of Ashtamudi is located in: SSC CPO 25/11/2020(Morning)

solution.explanation: Kerala (in Kollam District). It has a unique wetland ecosystem and a large palm shaped waterbody. Ashtamudi Wetland is included in the list of wetlands of international importance.

question: Which sanctuary is famous for endangered Estuarine Crocodiles conservation in India? SSC CHSL 13/10/2020(Morning)

solution.explanation: Bhitarkanika Wildlife Sanctuary (Odisha) is a Ramsar site and is one of India’s biggest estuarine crocodile habitats and a major coastal ecosystem.

question: Which wildlife sanctuary is a tri-state protected area in northern India? It is also famous for the Critically Endangered gharial, the red-crowned roofed turtle and the Endangered Ganges river dolphin? SSC CHSL 20/10/2020(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: National Chambal Sanctuary is located on the Chambal River near the tri-point of Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh.

question: In which district of Karnataka is the Brahmagiri Wildlife Sanctuary located? SSC CGL 03/3/2020 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Kodagu (Coorg). Brahmagiri Wildlife Sanctuary is situated on the border between Wayanad District of Kerala state on the south and Kodagu District in Karnataka on the north side.

question: Which National Park among the following is the largest protected area in the Eastern Himalayan sub-region? SSC CGL 05/3/2020 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Namdapha National Park (Arunachal Pradesh). It has more than 1,000 ﬂoral and about 1,400 faunal species. It is a biodiversity hotspot in the Eastern Himalayas. Physiographic Division of India

question: Select the correct order of the following plateaus and ranges from south to north in India. SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024

solution.explanation: Deccan Plateau: The southernmost plateau, covering parts of Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, and Telangana. Satpura Range: Located to the north of the Deccan Plateau and runs through Madhya Pradesh and www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography Maharashtra. Vindhya Range: Lies further north of the Satpura Range, stretching across Madhya Pradesh and separating the northern plains from the southern plateaus. Malwa Plateau: Located to the north of the Vindhya Range, covering parts of Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan.

question: In which of the following types of regions, is the maximum temperature variation observed between a day and the same night? SSC MTS 13/11/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Desert like the ‘Thar Desert’ experience extreme temperature variations due to low moisture, sparse vegetation, and clear skies. Daytime temperatures can reach up to 50°C, while nights drop to around 15°C, creating a difference of about 35°C in 24 hours.

question: Which physical feature of India prevents the cold winds from central Asia from entering the Indian subcontinent? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Himalaya : It acts as a natural barrier, blocking cold winds from Central Asia and protecting the climate of India. This mountain range effectively protects the subcontinent, and maintains its relatively warm temperatures. Coastal area : Allows winds from the sea to enter India.

question: In which of the following districts of Rajasthan are the ‘Barchans’ found? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Jaisalmer. Barchan, crescent-shaped sand dune produced by the action of wind predominately from one direction. The Indian desert lies west of the Aravali Hills, with sandy plains and sand dunes. It receives very low rainfall (below 150 mm annually) and has an arid climate with sparse vegetation.

question: Purvanchal Himalayas does NOT comprise of : SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Pir Panjal Range in the Himalayas is a part of the Lesser Himalayas. The Pir Panjal Range starts near PatniTop in Jammu and Kashmir and runs through Himachal Pradesh to Garhwal. The Purvanchal Himalayas, also known as the Eastern Hills, are a mountain range in northeastern India. This range includes the Patkai Hills, the Naga Hills in Nagaland, the Manipur Hills in Manipur, and the Mizo Hills in Mizoram.

question: Which of the following hills is located in the Eastern Ghats? SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Shevaroy hills. The Eastern Ghats are a series of discontinuous low hills with an average elevation of 600 meters. They extend parallel to the east coast, from the southern part of the Mahanadi valley to the Nilgiri hills. The highest peak in this region is Jindhagada Peak (1,690 meters). Notable hills in the Eastern Ghats include : Mahendragiri and Niyamgiri hills in Odisha, Nallamala hills (Andhra Pradesh), and Kollimalai and Pachaimalai hills in Tamil Nadu.

question: In the southern ranges of which hills is Mawsynram, which receives the highest rainfall in the world, located? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Khasi hills: These are part of the Meghalaya subtropical forests ecoregion and, along with the Garo and Jaintia Hills, contribute to the state of Meghalaya, meaning "abode of the clouds" in Sanskrit. Mawsynram, located about 16 kilometers west of Cherrapunji, is recognized as the wettest place on Earth, receiving a higher annual average rainfall than Cherrapunji.

question: What is the name of the highest peak of the Eastern Ghats? SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Mahendragir. This hill was once believed to be the highest peak in the Eastern Ghats. However, in April 2011, a team led by Mr. Venkat Reddy Y found that the elevation of Mahendra Giri Hill is actually 1,501 meters. Jindhagada Peak: After this discovery, it was determined that the highest peak in the Eastern Ghats is Jindhagada Peak, which stands at 1,690 meters. It is located in the Araku Valley in Andhra Pradesh.

question: Which sub-division of Himalayas are famous for Karewa formations ? SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Kashmir Himalayas. Karewa - thick deposits of glacial clay and moraines. These are the ﬂat topped mounds that border the Kashmir Valley on all sides. The other Himalayan sub-divisions are: Uttarakhand Himalayas: Between the Ravi and Kali rivers. Arunachal Himalayas: Between the Tista and Brahmaputra rivers. Sikkim Himalayas: Between the Kali and Teesta rivers.

question: The Lushai Hills are also known as _________. SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Mizo Hills (Mizoram and Manipur). The highest point of Mizo hills is the Blue Mountain. Eastern Hills (The Purvanchal) are the southward extension of Himalayas running along the north-eastern edge of India.

question: The central stretch of the Western Coastal Plains of India is known as the: SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Kannad plains (Between Goa and Mangalore). Malabar coast - Extends from the southern part of Goa to Kanyakumari.

question: The Himalayas' outermost range is called __________. SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Shiwaliks. They extend over a width of 10-50 Km and have an altitude varying between 900 and 1100 metres. They have low hills like Jammu Hills, etc. Pir Panjal and Dhauladhar are important ranges of lesser Himalayas.

question: In which direction is the general elevation of the peninsular plateau of India? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: From West to East. The Peninsular Plateau of India lies south of the Northern Plains, with an average elevation of 600-900 m. It consists of www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography smaller plateaus and hill ranges with river basins and valleys. The plateau is divided into three groups: Central Highlands (e.g., Malwa, Bundelkhand), Deccan Plateau (e.g., Maharashtra, Karnataka), and Northwestern Plateau (e.g., Aravalli, Vindhya, Satpura ranges).

question: Which of the following hills is located in the Eastern most part of India? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Patkai Bum Hills. Patkai Hills (Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Upper Burma region of Myanmar). Western Ghats {Anamudi (highest peak), Mannamala, Meesapulimala, Doddabetta peak, Kolaribetta Peak, etc). The Mizo Hills, located in the southeastern Mizoram state, were formerly called Lushai Hills.

question: What is the average elevation of the Eastern Ghats of India? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: 600 metres. Eastern Ghats comprises the discontinuous and low hills that are highly eroded by the rivers such as the Mahanadi, the Godavari, the Krishna, the Cauvery, etc. The Eastern Ghats are a mesmerising mountain range that extends across the states of Odisha, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu.

question: Choose the correct statements about the islands of India. a. Lakshadweep Islands are composed of coral islands. b. Andaman and Nicobar islands are composed of coral islands. c. It is believed that Lakshadweep islands are an elevated portion of submarine mountains. d. It is believed that Andaman and Nicobar islands are an elevated portion of submarine mountains. SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: a and d.

question: What is the name of the physical feature that is the longitudinal valley lying between the Lesser Himalayas and the Siwalik in India? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Duns are structurally formed valleys covered with boulders and gravel from the erosion of the Himalayas and Shivalik uplands. Major duns in the region include Dehra, Kohtri, Chaukham, Patli, and Kota, with Dehradun being the largest at 35 km long and 25 km wide.

question: The Himalayas have uplifted from which of the following geosynclines? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Tethys geosynclines. The northward drift of the Indian Plate resulted in the collision of the plate with the much larger Eurasian Plate. Due to this collision, the sedimentary rocks which were accumulated in the geosyncline known as the Tethys were folded to form the mountain system of western Asia and Himalaya.

question: What is the name of the northern part of the western coastal plain between Mumbai and Goa? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Konkan coast. The central stretch of Arabian Sea is called the Kannad Plain, while the southern stretch is known as the Malabar coast. In the Bay of Bengal, the northern part is called the Northern Circar, and the southern part is the Coromandel Coast.

question: Which of the following physiographic divisions of India has extensive alluvial soil ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: The North Indian Plain is formed by alluvial deposits brought by rivers such as the Indus, Ganga, and Brahmaputra. These plains stretch about 3,200 km from east to west and are divided into three zones: Bhabar, Tarai, and Alluvial plains. Bhabar is a narrow belt near the Shiwalik foothills, while Tarai lies south of it. The alluvial plains include the Khadar (new alluvium) and Bhangar (old alluvium).

question: The Great Indian desert/Thar desert is located on the western margin of which of the following mountain ranges? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Aravalli range. It runs approximately 670 km (430 mi) in a south-west direction, starting near Delhi, passing through southern Haryana and Rajasthan, and ending in Gujarat. The highest peak is Guru Shikhar at 1,722 metres (5,650 ft). Vindhya range forms a dividing line between the Ganges Plain and the Deccan Plateau. Satpura range is situated between two west ﬂowing rivers - Narmada and Tapi.

question: Choose the correct statements about the Western Ghats. a. The height of the Western Ghats progressively increases from north to south. b. Mahendragiri is the highest peak in the Western Ghats. c. The Western Ghats are higher than the Eastern Ghats. d. The height of the Western Ghats progressively decreases from north to south. SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: a and c. The highest peak in the Western Ghats is Anamudi (2,695 metres).

question: Which triangular plateau region of India lies south of the river Narmada? Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Deccan plateau. Its broad base is ﬂanked by the Satpura Range to the north, while the Mahadev, Kaimur Hills, and Maikal Range extend to the east. The Deccan Plateau is higher in the west and slopes gently eastwards.

question: Geologically, which of the following physiographic divisions of India is supposed to be one of the most stable land blocks? Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 3) a) The Northern Plains

solution.explanation: The Peninsular plateau is a tableland composed of the old crystalline, igneous and metamorphic rocks. This plateau consists of two broad divisions, namely, the Central Highlands and the Deccan Plateau. The part of the Peninsular plateau lying to the north of the Narmada river. The Indian desert lies towards the western margins of the www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography Aravali Hills. It is an undulating sandy plain covered with sand dunes. The northern plain is formed of alluvial soil. The Himalayas, geologically young and structurally fold mountains stretch over the northern borders of India.

question: With reference to the physical features of India, the ‘Kayals’ are _________. SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Backwaters: The inland water bodies, often formed by the merging of rivers and lakes or by the backﬂow of seawater, creating a network of interconnected waterways. In Kerala, these backwaters are locally known as kayals.

question: Which of the following physical divisions of India is densely populated? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: The North Indian Plains has been formed by the interplay of the three major river systems, namely the Indus, the Ganga and the Brahmaputra along with their tributaries, which makes its soil highly fertile. Alluvial soil is the major soil found in the plains. The swampy belt of the plains is known as terai.

question: India accounts for what percent of the total geographical area of the world ? SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 2.4 %. The land mass of India has an area of 3.28 million square km. India is the seventh largest country in the world. Largest countries in the world: Russia, Canada, China, United States, Brazil, Australia, etc.

question: The Standard Meridian of India (82°30’E) passes through _______ state of India. SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Madhya Pradesh. The Standard Meridian - A longitude that determines a standard time for the whole country.

question: Which of the following Indian states is biggest in terms of area? SSC MTS 15/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Rajasthan. Indian states biggest in terms of area: Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat. Smallest state (in terms of area) - Goa. Smallest Union Territories (in terms of area) - Lakshadweep, Daman and Diu, Chandigarh, Puducherry, Dadra and Nagar Haveli, Delhi.

question: India's total length of coastline of the mainland including Andaman and Nicobar and Lakshadweep is ________ SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 7516.6 km. Length of Coastline of the Indian mainland - 6100 km. The Coast of the Indian mainland is surrounded by Arabian Sea in the west, Bay of Bengal in the east , and Indian Ocean in the south. India's coastline extends to Nine states (Gujarat, Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, and West Bengal). Largest coastline - Gujarat (1214 km).

question: The plains from Ambala to the Sunderban stretch over nearly 1800 km, but the fall in its slope is hardly ________ metres. SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: 300. In other words, there is a fall of just one meter for every 6 km. Therefore, the river develops large meanders. Ambala is located on the water divide between the Indus and the Ganga river systems.

question: When the river approaches sea it breaks up into a number of distributaries, each distributary forms its own mouth. The collection of sediments from all the mouths forms _______. SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Delta. Meander is a pronounced curve or loop in the course of a river channel. Floodplains are an area of low-lying ground adjacent to a river, formed mainly by ﬂooding of rivers and the deposition of sand sediments on the riverbanks.

question: Devka Beach, a beautiful expanse of black sand is located in______ SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Daman. Radhanagar Beach (Havelock Island, Andaman). Juhu Beach, Mumbai. Ramakrishna Beach (Andhra Pradesh), Candolim Beach (Goa). Marina beach (Chennai) is India's longest and the world's second longest beach. Puri Beach (Golden beach), Odisha.

question: Which of the following factors are responsible for railways having not developed much in the north-eastern parts of India? (1) Highly dissected topography (2) Dense forests (3) Low population density (4) Heavy rainfall and frequent ﬂooding SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 1,2 and 4. The northeastern part of India is marked by the presence of big rivers, dissected relief, dense forests, frequent ﬂoods, landslides, international frontiers, etc. The ﬁrst railway proposals for India were made in Madras in 1832. As a result, the country got its ﬁrst train in the form of the Red Hill Railway which was built with the sole purpose of transporting granite for road-building in 1837.

question: Which of the following is a mountain pass in the Pir Panjal range at a maximum altitude of 2832 meters that connects the Kashmir Valley in the Union Territory of Jammu and Kashmir with the Outer Himalayas and the plains in the south? SSC CHSL 26/05/2022(Evening)

solution.explanation: Banihal pass (Jammu and Kashmir) is situated in the Pir - Panjal Range. It connects Banihal with Qazigund. Mana Pass (Uttarakhand) is located in the Greater Himalayas and connects Tibet with Uttarakhand. Bara lacha pass - Connects Himachal Pradesh's Lahaul area with Ladakh. Zojila Pass connects Leh and Srinagar.

question: With reference to the major regions of the northern plains, Bhabar is: SSC CHSL 09/06/2022 (Evening)

options.A: the older alluvium along the river beds
options.B: a narrow belt of about 8 to 16 km that
options.D: a broad long zone of northern India

solution.correct_answer: B. a narrow belt of about 8 to 16 km that
solution.explanation: Bhabar is a narrow belt lying parallel to the slopes of the Shiwaliks in Uttarakhand. It is narrow in the east and wide in the western and northwestern hilly regions. It comprises gravel and un-assorted sediment deposits. Crop cultivation is not possible in this tract, only giant trees with deep roots grow.

question: In which of the following regions of India is the natural habitat of White-bellied Heron largely distributed? SSC MTS 05/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: North-east India, the easternmost region of the country, comprises eight states: Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, and Sikkim.

question: Deserts, rain,forests, coral reefs, and mangroves are features of ________ diversity. SSC CGL 16/08/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Ecological diversity includes species diversity, genetic diversity, and ecosystem diversity. They are collectively considered biodiversity. It is the sum of all kinds of animals and plants living on this earth along with their habitat.

question: Which of the following is a district-cum-tourism hotspot of Arunachal Pradesh? SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Tawang. Kalimpong, Alipurduar, and Jalpaiguri are the districts in West Bengal.

question: The archaeological site of Atranjikhera is located in _______. SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Uttar Pradesh. This site was ﬁrst identiﬁed by Sir Alexander Cunningham in 1862 but excavated by R C Gaur in 1962.

question: In the state of ______, the general direction of the Himalayas is from southwest to northeast. SSC CHSL 11/8/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Arunachal Pradesh. Himalayas in the Darjeeling and Sikkim regions lie in an east-west direction.

question: Which of the following mountain is situated in the state of Uttarakhand? SSC CHSL 11/8/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Mangsha Dhura Pass. Other passes in Uttarakhand: Kalindi Pass, Lipulekh Pass, Mana Pass, Auden's Col, Muling La, Nama Pass, Niti Pass, Traill's Pass.

question: Which among the following states does NOT share its border with Odisha? SSC CPO 25/11/2020 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Bihar. Odisha is surrounded by 4 states: Andhra Pradesh from the south, Chhattisgarh from the west and Jharkhand and West Bengal from the north.

question: River Sutlej enters India through which pass? SSC CHSL 16/10/2020 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Shipki La - From here, Satluj traverses through many Himalayan valleys before it merges with Chenab in Pakistan before landing into Indus.

question: Which among the following is a western coast island? SSC CHSL 26/10/2020 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Elephanta island is located in Mumbai Harbour of the Arabian Sea. Pamban (between peninsular India and Sri Lanka), Parikud (Odisha), and Sriharikota (Andhra Pradesh). Transportation

question: What is the length of the Indian Railways network, according to the Railway Yearbook 2019-20 ? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: 67,956 km. The length of the Indian Railways network, according to the Railway Yearbook 2019-20 : Broad gauge - The distance between the rails is 1.676 meters, with a total length of 63,950 km. Metre gauge - The distance between the rails is 1 meter, with a total length of 2,402 km. Narrow gauge - The distance between the rails is either 0.762 meters or 0.610 meters, with a total length of 1,604 km.

question: According to the Indian Railways (2019-2020), which state has the largest railway track in India? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Uttar Pradesh. The longest railway track in India is the Dibrugarh-Kanyakumari Vivek Express (approx 4200 km), running from Dibrugarh in Assam to Kanyakumari in Tamil Nadu. The shortest railway line is the 3-kilometer route between Nagpur and Ajni in Maharashtra. The ﬁve states with the largest route kilometers are Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Andhra Pradesh.

question: In which of the following states is the development of rail transport less, due to its geographical conditions? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Sikkim is predominantly mountainous, characterized by steep slopes and rugged terrain, which complicates the construction of rail infrastructure.

question: Through which routes is the majority of India’s international trade carried out? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Sea and air. India has a coastline of approximately 7,516.6 km, making maritime transport essential for international trade. According to the Ministry of Shipping, about 95% of India's trade by volume and 70% by value is conducted via sea routes. A smaller portion of trade occurs through land routes to neighboring countries, including Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, and Pakistan.

question: According to the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways’ annual report (2020-2021), which position does India www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography have in terms of road networks in the world? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Second. India has the second largest road network in the world after the USA. India’s road network stands at over 63,71,847 km. This comprises National Highways, Expressways, State Highways, Major District Roads, other District Roads and Village Roads (Ministry of Road Transport & Highways Annual Report FY 2021-22).

question: As of Financial year 2019, which of the following states has the highest road density in India? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Kerala. As of the ﬁnancial year 2019, Kerala had the highest road density among states, with 6.7 thousand kilometers of roads per one thousand square kilometers. Among union territories, Chandigarh had the highest road density in India, with over 22.6 thousand kilometers per one thousand square kilometers. Road density refers to the total length of all roads in a country, including highways, national roads, and city or rural roads, compared to the country's land area.

question: By which National Waterways (NW) of India, are the delta channels of Mahanadi and Brahmani rivers and East Coast Canal connected? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: NW 5. It connects the states of Odisha and West Bengal, stretching 623 km in total, with 91 km in West Bengal and 532 km in Odisha. National Waterway-1 (NW-1) spans the Ganga-Bhagirathi-Hooghly river system from Prayagraj, Uttar Pradesh, to Haldia, West Bengal. National Waterway-2 covers 891 km of the Brahmaputra River between the Bangladesh border near Dhubri and Sadiya in Assam. National Waterway-3, also known as the West Coast Canal, is a 168 km route in Kerala from Kollam to Kottapuram.

question: About what percentage of passenger traﬃc is carried by roads in India? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 87%. The Road Transport Sector handles about 60% of freight traﬃc in India. For passenger traﬃc, roads account for 87%, railways for 12%, and both air and waterways contribute approximately 0.5% each, as per the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways.

question: Which of the following is an example of an eastern coast port? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Chennai Port started its commercial operations in 1881. The major ports on the eastern coast : Tuticorin - Tamil Nadu, Ennore - Tamil Nadu, Chennai - Tamil Nadu, Haldia and Kolkata - West Bengal, Paradip - Odisha, Visakhapatnam - Andhra Pradesh, Port Blair - Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

question: Which of the following ports was developed as a Satellite port to relieve the pressure at the Mumbai port? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru Port (Nhava Sheva), established on 26 May 1989, is India's second-largest container port, following Mundra Port. New Mangalore Port, in Karnataka, is operated by the New Mangalore Port Trust. Mormugao Port, commissioned in 1885, is located on Goa's western coast.

question: In which year was the Konkan Railway constructed? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: 1998. Indian Railways founded the Konkan Railway on 19th July 1990. Konkan Railways crosses 146 river streams, nearly 2000 bridges, and 91 tunnels. The states of Maharashtra, Goa, and Karnataka are partners in this undertaking.

question: The Atal Tunnel has been built by Border Road Organisation at an altitude of 3000 metres. Which places are connected by this tunnel? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Manali to Lahaul-Spiti. Atal Tunnel (also known as Rohtang Tunnel) is a highway tunnel built under the Rohtang Pass in the eastern Pir Panjal range of the Himalayas on the Leh-Manali Highway in Himachal Pradesh. It reduces the distance between Solang Valley and Sissu by approximately 46 km. Pir Panjal Railway Tunnel - India's longest transportation railway tunnel.

question: Match the following ports with their related states correctly. Ports States 1. Mormugao port a. West Bengal 2. Paradip Port b. Odisha 3. Haldia Port c. Tamil Nadu 4. Tuticorin Port d. Goa SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c. Other major ports of India: Andhra Pradesh - Visakhapatnam Port. Tamil Nadu - Kamarajar Port, Chennai Port, Tuticorin Port.

question: When was air transport nationalised in India? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: 1953. The Air Corporations Act of 1953 led to the nationalization of Indian airlines and the formation of two corporations: Indian Airlines for domestic routes and Air India International for international routes.

question: Match the railway zones in column A with their headquarters in column B. Column A (Railway zones) Column B (Headquarters) 1. Central a. New Delhi 2. Northern b. Mumbai CST 3. Eastern c. Chennai 4. Southern d. Kolkata SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)
The Howrah bridge was oﬃcially opened in the year _______. SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: 1943. The Howrah Bridge is a balanced steel bridge over the Hooghly River in West Bengal, India. At the time it was built the name given to it was the New Howrah Bridge. It was renamed Rabindra Setu in 1965 after the great Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore. But it is still popularly known by the name Howrah Bridge. www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

question: What is the total length of the Golden Quadrilateral, built by the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI)? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: 5846 km. The Golden Quadrilateral is a major highway network connecting four megacities in India: Delhi, Kolkata, Chennai, and Mumbai. The routes are Delhi-Kolkata via NH-2, Mumbai-Delhi via NH-8, Mumbai-Chennai via NH-4, and Chennai-Kolkata via NH-5. The National Highways Authority of India, established in 1988, operates under the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways.

question: Pipelines as a means of transport are looked after by the _________ of the Government of India. SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.correct_answer: A. Ministry of Petroleum and Natural
solution.explanation: Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas. Some major pipelines in India: Hazira-Bijaypur-Jagdishpur Pipeline - India's longest gas pipeline, which runs from Gujarat to Uttar Pradesh. Jamnagar-Loni LPG Pipeline - It transports LPG from Jamnagar to Loni near Delhi. Naharkatia-Nunmati-Barauni Pipeline - India's ﬁrst crude oil pipeline, which runs from Assam to the Barauni reﬁnery.

question: As of 2022, which of the following is the longest national waterway in India? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Allahabad-Haldia stretch (1,620 km). It is divided into three parts for developmental purposes - (i) Haldia-Farakka (560 km), (ii) Farakka-Patna (460 km), (iii) Patna Allahabad (600 km). National Waterways (NW) of India : NW 2 - Sadiya-Dhubri stretch (891 km). NW 3 - Kottapuram-Kollam stretch (205 km). NW 4 - Speciﬁc stretches of Godavari and Krishna rivers along with Kakinada-Puducherry stretch of canals (1078 km). NW 5 - Speciﬁed stretches of river Brahmani along with Matai river, delta channels of Mahanadi and Brahmani rivers and East Coast canals (588 km).

question: How many major ports are there in India for maritime transportation? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 13. Ports and State : Chennai Port (Tamil Nadu), Ennore Port (Tamil Nadu), Shyama Prasad Mukherji Port (West Bengal), Deendayal Port (Gujarat), Kochi Port (Kerala), Port Blair (Andaman and Nicobar Islands), New Mangalore Port (Karnataka), Mormugao (Goa), Mumbai Port (Maharashtra), Paradip Port (Odisha), Tuticorin Port (Tamil Nadu).

question: The historical Sher Shah Suri Marg is called the National Highway no. _________ between Delhi and Amritsar. Graduate Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: 1. Sher Shah Suri built the Shahi (Royal) Road to strengthen and consolidate his empire from the Indus Valley to Bengal's Sonar Valley. This road was renamed the Grand Trunk (GT) Road during British rule, connecting Kolkata and Peshawar. Currently, it extends from Amritsar to Kolkata and is divided into two segments: National Highway (NH)-1 from Delhi to Amritsar and NH-2 from Delhi to Kolkata.

question: In which of the following years was the air transport in India launched? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 1911. Air Transportation: Air transport in India was launched between Allahabad and Naini (10 km). George Light started Air Transport in India. The ﬁrst airmail ﬂight was piloted by French pilot Henri Pequet. Air transport was nationalised and two Corporations, Air India International and Indian Airlines were formed in 1953.

question: In India, which of the following modes of transportation reduces trans-shipment losses and delays in supply of petroleum and gas? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Pipelines are cost-effective and can transport large volumes of liquids or gasses over long distances with minimal environmental impact. Advantages - Dedicated Infrastructure, Minimized Handling, Continuous Flow, Cost-Effective, Environmental Beneﬁts, Energy Eﬃciency, Reduces Congestion. Naharkatia-Noonmati -Barauni Pipeline is the ﬁrst crude oil pipeline constructed in India. Jamnagar-Loni LPG Pipeline is India's longest pipeline.

question: Which of the following is NOT a part of the six communication mail channels in India? SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Monthly Channel. The six communication mail channels in India: Rajdhani (Yellow colored mailboxes are installed at post oﬃces), Metro (Blue colored mailboxes are installed at post oﬃces), Green (Green colored mailboxes are installed at post oﬃces in large and metropolitan cities), Business (Physical mail that is commercial in nature), Periodical (Intended for newspapers, magazines, and other periodical publications) and Bulk (Consists of letters, newsletters, leaﬂets, and other similar products).

question: How many phases are involved in the census operations in India? SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024

solution.explanation: Two. First - Houselisting/Housing Census under which details of all buildings, permanent or temporary, are noted with their type, amenities, and assets. Second - Population Enumeration where more detailed information on each individual residing in the country, Indian national or otherwise is noted. The ﬁrst non-synchronous census was conducted in 1872 under Lord Mayo's administration, while the ﬁrst synchronous census took place in 1881 under W.C. Plowden. The 16th Census (2021) was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

question: As per the deﬁnition of Census of India, a ‘marginal worker’ is a person who works for: SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.B: more than 183 days (or six months) in

solution.correct_answer: A. less than 183 days (or six months) in
solution.explanation: The population of India according to their economic status is divided into three groups, namely; main workers, marginal workers and non-workers. A Main Worker is a person who works for at least 183 days (or six months) in a year. Marginal Worker is a person who works for less than 183 days (or six months) in a year. question: Who published the logistic equation model of population growth in 1838 ? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Pierre François Verhulst. He was a Belgian mathematician who earned a doctorate in number theory from the University of Ghent in 1825. He is renowned for the logistic growth model, which is widely applied in population growth modeling. This model, ﬁrst proposed by Pierre-François Verhulst in 1838, states that the reproduction rate is proportional to both the existing population and the available resources, assuming all else is equal.

question: The __________ results from an increase in the proportion of workers relative to nonworkers in the population. SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (3rd shift)

question: Atmospheric temperature usually decreases with altitude, but sometimes this phenomenon gets reversed in the troposphere. This phenomenon is known as _________. SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Temperature Inversion occurs when the normal pattern of temperature decreasing with altitude is reversed, and the air becomes warmer as you go higher. This phenomenon can lead to air pollution problems and is often seen in valleys or areas with stagnant air. Adiabatic lapse rate: Change of temperature with a change in altitude of an air parcel without gaining or losing any heat to the environment surrounding the parcel. Temperature Convection - The process by which heat is transferred through the movement of ﬂuid (like air or water) due to temperature differences.

question: What kind of radiation is absorbed by the ozone layer? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Ultraviolet radiation. The UV radiation spectrum is divided into three types : UVA, UVB and UVC. These rays can affect our skin in different ways. Ozone layer : It is a region in the Earth's stratosphere that contains a high concentration of ozone (O3) gas. This layer acts as a shield, protecting the Earth from the Sun's harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Infrared radiation (IR), also known as thermal radiation, is that band in the electromagnetic radiation spectrum with wavelengths above red visible light between 780 nm to 1mm (0.78 μm to 1000 μm).

question: A dense mass of water drops on smoke or dust particles in the lower atmosphere layers is referred to as: SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: smog. Fog forms when an air mass with high water vapor suddenly cools, causing condensation on ﬁne dust particles. It is essentially a cloud at or near the ground, leading to poor visibility, often reduced to zero. Fog is denser and thicker than mist. Fog reduces visibility to less than one kilometer, while mist reduces visibility to one to two kilometers. Frost forms on cold surfaces when condensation takes place below freezing point (00C), i.e. the dew point is at or below the freezing point.

question: The upper portion of the earth is known as: SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Lithosphere. It is bounded by the atmosphere above and the asthenosphere (another part of the upper mantle) below. The stratosphere is the second-lowest layer of Earth's atmosphere. The troposphere, the lowest layer of the atmosphere, contains about 75-80% of the atmospheric mass. Most clouds form in the troposphere, where nearly all weather occurs. The mesosphere is the third highest layer, situated between the stratosphere and the thermosphere.

question: The zone separating the troposphere from the stratosphere is called the __________. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Tropopause. The air temperature at the tropopause is about - 80o C over the equator and about - 45o C over the poles. The temperature in this region is nearly constant, and hence, it is called the tropopause. The stratosphere is found above the tropopause and extends up to a height of 50 km. One important feature of the stratosphere is that it contains the ozone layer.

question: All the changes in climate and weather takes place in _________. SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Troposphere. It is the lowermost layer of the atmosphere and is often referred to as the "region of mixing”. Its average height is 13 km and extends roughly to a height of 8 km near the poles and about 18 km at the www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography equator. Stratosphere (contains the ozone layer) - 2nd layer of the Earth's atmosphere, extending from about 10 to 50 km in altitude. Mesosphere - 3rd layer of the Earth's atmosphere, extending from about 50 to 85 km in altitude. Most meteors burn up in this atmospheric layer. Thermosphere - 4th layer of the Earth's atmosphere, extending from about 85 to 500 km in altitude.
