question: The term ‘monsoon’ is derived from a/an: SSC CHSL 21/10/2020 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Arabic word 'mausim', meaning weather, was ﬁrst used in English in British India to refer to seasonal changes in wind direction. Rocks

question: The igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks are interconvertible through a continuous process called: SSC MTS 08/10/2024 (3rd Shift) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

solution.correct_answer: C. rock cycle (d) weathering and erosion
solution.explanation: rock cycle. It is a series of processes that create and transform the types of rocks in Earth's crust. Lithiﬁcation: This is speciﬁcally the process by which sediments are compacted and cemented to form sedimentary rocks. Metamorphism is the process by which existing rocks (Igneous, Sedimentary, or even other Metamorphic rocks) are transformed into metamorphic rocks under high pressure, and temperature. Weathering and erosion: These are processes that break down existing rocks into smaller particles.

question: The layer made up of unconsolidated rock, dust, soil, etc. that is deposited on a bed rock surface like a blanket is known as: SSC MTS 09/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Regolith. It can be found both at the surface and at varying depths. This layer of fragmented soil material forms the outermost covering of the land and is present almost everywhere, covering the underlying bedrock. Regolith is primarily inorganic and acts like a blanket over unbroken rock.

question: Layers of varying thickness are found in which type of rock? SSC MTS 22/10/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Sedimentary rocks are formed by the deposition and compaction of sediments over time, often in layers. These layers, also called strata. Examples - Sandstone, conglomerate, limestone, shale, loess. Igneous rocks (primary rocks) form out of magma and lava from the interior of the earth. Examples - Granite, gabbro, pegmatite. Metamorphic Rocks form under the action of pressure, volume and temperature changes. Examples - Gneissoid, granite, syenite, slate.

question: Exfoliation is a form of _________. SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Physical weathering is caused by the effects of changing temperature on rocks, causing the rock to break apart. The process is sometimes assisted by water. Exfoliation occurs as cracks develop parallel to the land surface, a consequence of the reduction in pressure during uplift and erosion.

question: The outermost part of the Earth is known as __________. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: the crust. The Earth's crust is the thinnest of all its layers, about 35 km thick on the continental masses and only 5 km on the ocean ﬂoors. The main minerals in the continental crust are silica and alumina, while the oceanic crust consists primarily of silica and magnesium. Beneath the crust lies the mantle, which extends to a depth of 2900 km. The innermost layer is the core, with a radius of about 3500 km, made mostly of nickel and iron.

question: Which of the following is the correct match between column-A and column-B? Column-A (Type of rock) Column-B (Method of formation) i. Sedimentary Rock a. Transformed its chemical qualities from other type of rocks ii. Metamorphic Rock b. Derived from magma that was poured out or ejected at the Earth's Surface iii. Igneous Rock c. Formed from fragments of other rocks or the remains of plants or animals SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: i-c, ii-a, iii-b. The rock cycle is a web of processes that outlines how each of the three major rock types - igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary - form and break down based on the different applications of heat and pressure over time.

question: Structural geology deals with: SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Petrology is the science of rocks. Rock: Any natural mass of mineral matter that makes up the Earth's crust.

question: Which of the following is a yellowish green to green coloured gemstone often found in maﬁc and ultramaﬁc igneous rocks such as basalt, gabbro, dunite, diabase and peridotite? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Olivine. The mineral olivine is a magnesium iron silicate with the chemical formula (Mg,Fe)2SiO4. It is a type of nesosilicate or orthosilicate. Bornite, also known as peacock ore, is a sulﬁde mineral with a chemical composition of Cu5FeS4.

question: The steep rocky coast rising almost vertically above sea water is called ______. SSC MTS 06/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Sea cliffs are steep faces of rock and soil that are formed by destructive waves. A sea cave is a cave formed on a cliff by the wave action of an ocean or lake. A sea arch is a natural arch or bridge made of stone that has been created when water wears away the underside of a rock, leaving just the top behind.

question: The core of the Great Himalayas is composed of ______. SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Granite rock (Igneous rock). Lesser Himalaya consists of metamorphosed sedimentary rocks (quartzite, marble, slate, phyllite, schist and gneiss).

question: Which of the following determines the colour, texture,chemical properties, mineral, content and permeability of the soil? SSC MTS 22/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Parent rock . The color in the soil is mainly due to two factors – organic content and the chemical nature of iron compounds found in the soil.

question: How many types of igneous rocks www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography are there? SSC MTS 26/07/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Two. Based on the texture of rocks, igneous rocks are classiﬁed into Intrusive igneous rocks (Plutonic rocks) and Extrusive igneous rocks (Lava or Volcanic rocks).

question: Mushroom rocks are formed due to _____. SSC MTS 26/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Wind erosion. A mushroom rock (perched rock) is a typical mushroom-shaped landform that is formed by the action of wind erosion. These rocks are mostly found in arid regions. Such rocks are found in the Thar Desert of India.

question: What type of rocks were once igneous or sedimentary, but have metamorphosed as a result of intense heat and/or pressure within the Earth's crust? SSC CHSL 25/05/2022(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Quartzite. Granite is a coarse-grained (phaneritic) intrusive igneous rock composed mostly of quartz, alkali feldspar, and plagioclase. Sandstone is a clastic sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized silicate grains. Basalt is a maﬁc extrusive rock, is the most widespread of all igneous rocks, and comprises more than 90% of all volcanic rocks.

question: Which of the following rocks ﬂoats in water? SSC MTS 26/10/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Pumice is a light-colored, extremely porous igneous rock that forms during explosive volcanic eruptions. Obsidian has been used for tools and ornaments. Granite is a hard igneous rock made of quartz, feldspar, and mica. Slate is a metamorphic rock.

question: ________ plains are formed due to the weathering of soluble rocks such as limestone and dolomite. SSC CHSL 04/08/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Karst regions contain aquifers that are capable of providing large supplies of water. Typical karst forms include sinkholes, caves, natural bridges and sinking streams. Mountain

question: Which of the following mountain peaks is located in the Karakoram Range? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: K2, also known as Mount Godwin Austen (8,611 meters), is the world’s second-highest peak in the Karakoram range, spanning Pakistan, China, India, and extending into Afghanistan and Tajikistan. Trishul Peak is in the Himalayas, while Kamet Peak (7,756 meters) is the highest in the Zanskar range. Nanda Devi (7,817 meters) is the third-highest peak in the Himalayas.

question: Which of the following mountains of India is famous for tea and coffee production? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Nilgiri Hills are where the Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats meet. They are located at the tri-junction of Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. The highest peak in this region is Doda Betta. The Aravalli Range is known for its mineral resources, such as copper and zinc. The Himalayas are famous for saffron cultivation in the Kashmir region.

question: What is the name of the highest peak of Indian Garhwal Himalayas located in Chamoli district of Uttarakhand state with a height of 7,816 metres ? Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: Nanda Devi. It is the second-highest mountain in India, after Kangchenjunga (8598 m), and the highest entirely within the country. It ranks as the 23rd highest peak in the world. The Garhwal Himalayas lie between the Sutlej and the Kali river and is 320 km long. It is a part of the Himalayan Shivalik Hills (outermost hills of the Himalayas found in Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand).

question: The Garo, Khasi and Jaintia hills are a subdivision of: SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Meghalaya Plateau. The plateau is separated from the main block of the peninsular plateau by a gap called the Garo-RajMahal gap. It is located on the northeastern ﬂank of Peninsular India. It is one of the rainiest, most tectonically active areas in the world. Hills in North East India - Lushai Hills or Mizo Hills (Mizoram and Tripura), Chin Hills (Manipur to Chin State of Myanmar), Japfu Mountain Range (Nagaland), Barail Range (Assam), Daﬂa Hills and Abor Hills (Arunachal Pradesh).

question: The holy mountain 'Kailash' is located in which neighbouring country of India ? SSC MTS 01/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: China. Mount Kailash - Located near Lake Mansarovar and Lake Rakshastal. The Indus River originates from Mansarovar lake (Tibet). Some highest mountain peaks : India - Kanchenjunga (8598m), Nanda Devi (7817m). Nepal - Mount Everest (8848.86 m), Dhaulagiri (8172m). Hindu temple outside India : Nepal - Pashupatinath Temple, Indonesia - Prambanan Temple, Bangladesh - Dhakeshwari temple, Cambodia - Angkor Wat.

question: Name an oval-shaped range of hills sculpted by glacial ﬂow. SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Drumlins - It is formed by the ﬁlling of heavy rocky debris in the glacial crevices and its stay under the ice. One end of the drumlins facing the glacier called the stoss end and the other end called tail. Eskers: When glaciers melt in summer, the water ﬂows on the surface of the ice. These waters accumulate beneath the glacier and ﬂow like streams in a channel beneath the ice.

question: The Shevaroy Hills are located in which state of India? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Tamil Nadu (Aanna Malai, Doddabetta, Nilgiri). Famous hills:- Chhattisgarh - Tulasi Dongar, Bailadila, Balaraja Gutta. Odisha - Devmali, Turia Konda, Mahendragiri, Devagiri. Rajasthan www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography - Guru Shikhar, Mt. Abu, Sunda. Kangchenjunga (Sikkim) - Highest mountain peak in India.

question: Which among the following is the highest peak of West Bengal? SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Sandakphu (3636 m). It is located on the border between India and Nepal, belongs to the Singalia Mountain ranges. It is a part of the Purvanchal range. Doddabetta (2637 m) - It is the highest peak of Tamil Nadu and a part of Nilgiri Mountain Range.

question: The Himalayan Mountain range was formed by the collision of ________. SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.correct_answer: D. Indian Plate and Eurasian Plate
solution.explanation: Indian Plate and Eurasian Plate. Plates - They are large, rigid pieces of the Earth's lithosphere that ﬁt together like a jigsaw puzzle, and their movements are responsible for shaping the Earth's surface through processes such as earthquakes and the formation of mountains. Major plates (7) - African Plate, Antarctic Plate, Eurasian Plate, North American Plate, South American Plate, Paciﬁc Plate and Indo-Australian Plate.

question: Dhinodhar Hills is located in which Indian state/Union Territory? SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Gujarat. Dhinodhar Hill is a tourist and pilgrimage spot. Other hills in Gujarat - Chotila, Pavagadh, Palitana, Saputara, Girnar, Bardo, Gabbar. Hills : Maharashtra - Mahabaleshwar, Panchgani, Matheran, Lonavala, Amboli etc. West Bengal - Gorgaburu Hill, Ajodhya Hills, Susunia Hill etc. Andaman and Nicobar Islands - Ross Island, Barren Island, Saddle Peak, Katchal, Narcondam Island etc.

question: Which among the following peaks is the highest peak of Jharkhand? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Parasnath. It is named after Lord Parshvanath (23rd Jain Tirthankara). Kangto peak (Arunachal Pradesh). State and Highest Peak - Gujarat (Girnar Peak), Rajasthan (Guru Shikhar), Andhra Pradesh (Arma Konda), Haryana (Karah Peak), Karnataka (Mullayanagiri Peak).

question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (4th Shift)

options.A: Mahendragiri is the highest peak in the
options.B: The height of the Western Ghats
options.D: The Eastern Ghats stretch from the

solution.correct_answer: B. The height of the Western Ghats
solution.explanation: The height of the Western Ghats progressively increases from north to south. The highest peaks of Western Ghats include the Anai Mudi (2,695 metres) and the Doda Betta (2,637 meters).The Western Ghats, also known as the Sahyadri Hills, Mainly traverse the States of Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Goa, Maharashtra and Gujarat.

question: Which among the following is the largest of all the duns of the Shiwaliks mountain range in India? SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
Kalsubai peak is located in which of the following Indian states? SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Maharashtra. Kalsubai (Everest of Maharashtra) is the highest peak of Maharashtra’s Ahmednagar district in Akola taluka.

question: Which of the following is NOT a type of a fold mountain? SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Rhine Valley. Fold mountains are the most common type of mountain in the world. The rugged, soaring heights of the Himalayas, Andes, Alps and Aravalli Range (oldest range) are all active fold mountains. Rhine Valley (Germany) is the valley of the river Rhine in Europe. It is also known as Alpine Rhine. The Appalachian Mountains are found in North America.

question: The approximate length of the Great Himalayan range, also known as the central axial range, is _________ km from east to west. SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: 2500. The great Himalayan range width varies between 160-400 km from north to south. Famous peaks of Himalayas: Mount Everest (8848 m), Mt. Kanchenjunga (8598 m), Mt. Makalu (8481 m), Mt. Dhaulagiri (8172 m). The Himalayas consist of three parallel ranges - Himadri (Great Himalayas or the Higher Himalayas), Himachal (Lesser Himalayas or the Lower Himalayas) and Shiwaliks (Outer Himalayas).

question: What is the average height of inner Himalayas? SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: 6000 metres. The Himalayas consist of three parallel ranges, the Greater Himalayas or the Inner Himalayas or the Himadri, the Lesser Himalayas called the Himachal (with an average height of 3,700 to 4500 meters), and the Shivalik hills (with an average height of 900 to 1100 meters), which comprise the foothills.

question: Asia is separated from Europe by ______ mountains. SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ural. It is formed as a result of the compression of tectonic plates, leading to the formation of large fold-like structures on the Earth's crust. Alps mountain (natural boundary between France and Italy), Andes Mountains range (South American countries of Chile and Argentina), Himalaya (plains of the Indian subcontinent from the Tibetan Plateau). Caucasus mountains (Asia and Europe).

question: Which of the following have mountain range young fold mountains? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Alps mountain range. Fold mountains form when two or more of the Earth's tectonic plates collide. Types - Anticline, Syncline, Monocline, Isocline. Features - Rugged relief, imposing height (lofty), high conical peaks. Examples are the Rockies, the Andes, the Alps, the Himalayas, etc. Old fold Mountain - An Appalachian mountain range, Aravali mountain range, and Ural mountain range.

question: The uplifted blocks of block mountains are called ______. SSC MTS 14/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Horsts. Block mountains are formed due to the upward movement of the middle block between two normal faults. The up-thrown block is also called a horst. Graben is bounded by normal faults dipping toward each other. These mountains include the Great African Rift Valley , the Rhine Valley (graben) in Germany, etc.

question: Fotu La, the Great Mountain Pass, at an altitude of 4108 m above sea level, is the highest point of which Indian state/UT? SSC CHSL 09/06/2022(Morning)

solution.explanation: Ladakh. Fatu La is a mountain pass on the Srinagar-Leh highway in the Zanskar Range of the Himalayas in Ladakh, UT. It is one of two high mountain passes between Leh and Kargil, the other being Namika La.

question: Which of the following is also known as the ‘White Mountain’? SSC CGL 11/04/2022(Morning)

solution.explanation: Dhaulagiri is in west-central Nepal. Cho Oyu lies on the Nepal-Tibet border. Makalu is southeast of Everest, on the Nepal-Tibet border. Lhotse is on the border between Tibet and Nepal's Khumbu region.

question: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding mountains? I - Mountains may be arranged in a line known as range. II- The Aravali range in India is one of the oldest fold mountain systems in the world. III- Mt. Kilimanjaro in South America is an example of Volcanic Mountain SSC CGL 11/04/2022(Evening )

solution.explanation: Only I and II. Mount Kilimanjaro is a dormant volcano in Tanzania. It is the highest mountain in Africa . It was formed when molten rock from the depths of the earth rose from the crust and piled up on its own. Top mountains in Africa:- Mount Kenya, Mount Stanley, Mount Speke, Mount Baker, Mount Emin.

question: The Deomali is the highest mountain peak of ______. SSC CGL 12/04/2022(Morning)

solution.explanation: Odisha. The Deomali peak height is 1,762 m. The Borail Range is the highest Mountain Ranges in Assam. Someshwar Fort is the highest peak of Bihar. It is part of Shivalik hill.

question: In which Indian state will you ﬁnd Mount Tiyi? SSC CGL 12/04/2022(Evening)

solution.explanation: Nagaland. Some other mountains: Japfu Peak, Changkikong Range, Mount Saramati, Veda Peak, Ongpangkong Range.

question: In which of the following Indian states is the Gorichen peak located? SSC CGL 13/04/2022(Evening)

solution.explanation: Arunachal Pradesh. Gorichen Peak (6858 m) is the highest peak in Arunachal Pradesh, Dhupgarh is the highest in Madhya Pradesh, and Reo Purgyil is the highest in Himachal Pradesh.

question: Mountaineers refer to altitudes above about _______ meters as the ‘death zone’. SSC CGL 19/04/2022(Evening)

solution.explanation: 8,000. The death zone refers to altitudes where oxygen pressure is too low to sustain human life for extended periods.

question: Which of the following is a mountain peak that rises above the surrounding peaks at the mountainous border of the Indian state of Nagaland and the Sagaing region of Myanmar? SSC MTS 26/10/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Mount Saramati. Doddabetta is the highest mountain in the Nilgiri Mountains at 2,637 meters. Kalsubai (highest point) is a mountain in the Western Ghats, located in the Indian state of Maharashtra.

question: Generally, a steep hill with an elevation of more than _______ meters is classiﬁed as a mountain. SSC MTS 02/11/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: 600. Within the earth, a continuous movement is taking place. The internal process leads to the upliftment and sinking of the earth's surface at several places. The external process is the continuous wearing down and rebuilding of the land surface. Eg: Erosion and Deposition.

question: _______ is created by the collision of convergent plate boundaries. SSC CGL 16/08/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Mountain building. A convergent boundary is an area on earth where two or more lithospheric plates converge or collide and one plate eventually slides beneath the other.

question: 'Pidurutalagala' is the highest mountain peak in ______. SSC CHSL 15/04/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Sri Lanka. Pidurutalagala (Mount Pedro) is the tallest mountain in Sri Lanka, standing at 2,524 m in Nuwara Eliya.

question: Which of the following hills is situated in Assam? SSC CHSL 15/04/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Karbi Anglong Hills. Javadi Hills and Shevaroy Hills are located in Tamil Nadu.

question: Where is Mount Diavolo, an important mountain peak in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Located? www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography SSC CHSL 05/08/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: South Andaman. It has an elevation of 295 meters. Middle Andaman is separated from North Andaman Island by Austen Strait, and from Baratang Island at the south by Homfray's Strait.

question: Mount Jopuno is situated in which of the following states? SSC CHSL 09/8/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Sikkim. Mount Jopuno, located in western Sikkim at 5,603 meters, is situated within Khangchendzonga National Park.

question: Which of the following hills is situated in Andhra Pradesh? SSC CHSL 10/8/2021(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Nagari hills. Other hill stations in Andhra Pradesh include Tirumala, Araku Valley, Horsley Hills, Lambasingi, Nallamala Hills.

question: In which of the following states is the Shatrunjaya Hills located? SSC CHSL 10/8/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Gujarat. Other prominent hills in Gujarat include– Bhujia Hill, Dhinodhar, Girnar, Kalo Dungar, Pavagadh Hill, Thaltej-Jodhpur Tekra, Wilson Hills.

question: Which of the following mountains is situated near the Siachen region of Ladakh in India? SSC CHSL 20/10/2020(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: K12 Mountain. Kirat Chuli Mountain or Tent Peak is a mountain in the Himalayas. Kabru is a mountain in the Himalayas on the border of eastern Nepal and India. Kanchenjunga is part of the Great Himalaya Range. K12 is the second highest peak in the Saltoro Mountains, a subrange of the Karakoram range in the Siachen region, in Ladakh.

question: Borra Caves are situated on the East Coast of India in which of the following hills? SSC CGL 03/3/2020(Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Ananthagiri Hills. Borra Caves, also called Borra Guhalu, are located on the East Coast of India, in the Ananthagiri hills of the Araku Valley of the Visakhapatnam district in Andhra Pradesh. Volcano

question: Which of the following types of volcanic eruptions of Earth’s volcanoes are most explosive? SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Caldera. A caldera eruption is the most explosive type of volcanic activity, occurring when a volcano's magma chamber empties and the ground above collapses, forming a large, circular depression. Example: Yellowstone Caldera. Dykes: It is a vertical or steeply inclined geological formation that occurs when magma cuts through rock layers and solidiﬁes. Flood basalt provinces: Flood basalt refers to large, extensive lava ﬂows that spread out over vast areas. Example: Deccan Traps in India.

question: What is the name of the process of gases being outpoured from the interior of the solid earth ? Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Degassing is the process by which gases are released from the interior of the solid Earth, typically through volcanic activity or other geological processes. This includes gases such as water vapor, carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, and others that are expelled from magma or other subsurface materials.

question: Which of the following statements is best related to the 'paciﬁc ring of ﬁre'? SSC MTS 14/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. Known for volcano and earthquakes
solution.explanation: The 'ring of ﬁre' is a ring of volcanoes in the Paciﬁc Ocean. World Geography and Map

question: Where is the Gulf of Mannar located? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.A: Between the south-eastern tip of India
options.C: Between the south-eastern tip of India

solution.correct_answer: B. Between the south-eastern tip of
solution.explanation: Gulf of Mannar: It is located in the Coromandel Coast region. The Gulf of Mannar is separated from the Palk Bay by a chain of islands and coral reefs known as Adam's Bridge or Ram Setu. It is bound to the northeast by Rameswaram (island), Adam’s (Rama’s) Bridge (a chain of shoals), and Mannar Island.

question: Which of the following is the largest inhabited riverine island in the world? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Majuli is a famous island in the River Brahmaputra, ﬂowing in the state of Assam. It is the biggest district island in the country and is quite close to Jorhat. The island is formed by the Brahmaputra River in the south and the Kherkutia Xuti, an anabranch of the Brahmaputra, joined by the Subansiri River in the north.

question: A long, winding ridge of stratiﬁed sand and gravel is known as: SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Esker. An esker is formed by meltwater ﬂowing beneath a retreating glacier or ice sheet during the last Ice Age. This debris was deposited through tunnels and channels under the ice, leaving behind a hill or mound once the ice melted. Eskers are commonly found in regions that were once glaciated, such as Canada, Northern Europe, and parts of the United States.

question: How much percentage of Earth's water make up the oceans? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 97%. Water covers 71 percent of Earth's surface. Distribution of Earth’s water: Oceans (97.2%), Glaciers (2.1%), Groundwater (0.61 percent); Freshwater lakes (0.009 percent), Inland seas (0.008 percent), Soil Moisture (0.005 percent), Atmosphere (0.001 percent), Rivers (0.0001 percent).

question: Which of the following are some regions in the world, known for their thriving citrus fruit production? SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023

solution.explanation: Mediterranean regions - These are known as ‘Orchards of the world’. Plants grow in Mediterranean regions - Citrus fruits like lemons, orange and grapefruit, Rosemary, Olive. Mediterranean woodlands are found in the Mediterranean Sea region, Central Chile, the Southwest United States, Australia, and Africa.

question: Copacabana beach is situated in __________. SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Brazil. Copacabana beach: It is located in the South Zone of the city of Rio de Janeiro. Some famous Beaches in the world: Praia do Cassino (“Cassino beach”) is the longest beach in the world, located in Brazil. Monolithi beach, Greece (longest beach of Europe), Marina beach, Chennai (longest beach in Asia). Beaches in India - Puri Beach (Odisha), Rushikonda Beach (Andhra Pradesh), Eden Beach (Puducherry), Radhanagar beach (Andaman and Nicobar), Minicoy Thundi beach (Lakshadweep).

question: What is the name of the geographic feature that serves as a boundary between Europe and Africa ? SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Strait of Gibraltar separates Morocco and Spain. It joins the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. Bosporus Strait (the narrowest strait of the world)- It is a natural strait connecting the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara. Dardanelles strait (separates Asian Turkey from European Turkey) - It connects the Aegean Sea with the Sea of Marmara. Malacca Strait (Separates Malay Peninsula and Indonesian Island of Sumatra) - Connects the Andaman Sea (Indian Ocean) and the South China Sea (Paciﬁc Ocean).

question: Mid-latitude deserts (BWK) are found between 35° and _________N and S, which are poleward of subtropical high- pressure areas. SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: 60°. Mid-latitude deserts - An excessively dry region with an arid climate. Location - Found in the interior parts of the continents. Examples - Argentina's Patagonian Desert (Argentina), Gobi Desert (China and Mongolia), Turkestan (Kazakhstan), Ladakh (Jammu and Kashmir). Crops - Cacti, Prickly Shrubs, Long-rooted wiry grasses.

question: According to the World Bank, what was the density of the population of Sri Lanka in 2020? SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 4th shift)

solution.explanation: 354 Persons per sq . km. Other Countries' population density (Food and Agriculture Organization and World Bank population estimates in 2020) in square Km:- India (470), China (150), Myanmar (82), Nepal (205), Bangladesh (1286), New Zealand (19).

question: Which of the following combinations of "animal" and "area they found" is INCORRECT ? SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 4th shift)

solution.explanation: Orangutans - Caribbean islands. Scientiﬁc name (Pongo), Family (Hominidae). These are large, orange-haired apes that are native to the rainforests of Borneo and Sumatra. Kangaroos: Scientiﬁc name (Macropodidae), Phylum (Chordata). Ostriches: Phylum (Chordata), found in savanna and desert regions. Lemurs: Scientiﬁc name (Lemuroidea), Phylum (Chordata), found in Madagascar.

question: As of 2020, which country has the largest proven coal reserves in the world? SSC CHSL Tier II (26/06/2023)

solution.explanation: The United States of America (Largest Coal Reserves). Largest coal producer (1st China, 2nd India). Jharia Coal Field (Jharkhand) produces the highest coal in India. Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research (2007) - Dhanbad. Largest Producer: Bauxite (Australia), Gold (China), Diamond (Russia), Silver (Mexico), Chromium (South Africa), Copper (Chile), Uranium (Kazakhstan), Thorium (India).

question: "Eskimos" are associated with which geographical region? SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Polar Region (the area around the Earth’s North Pole or the South Pole). Igloo (small hut-like house made of snow where Eskimos live). Arid regions are dry and have little rainfall. Example - Central and western Asia, North and South America, central and northwest Australia.

question: Which sea separates Africa from the Arabian peninsula ? SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Red Sea. It extends southeast from Suez, Egypt (initially as the Gulf of Suez), for about 1,200 mi (1,930 km) to the Strait of Mandeb, which connects with the Gulf of Aden and then with the Arabian Sea. The Black Sea separates Europe from Asia. White Sea - A southern inlet of the Barents Sea located on the northwest coast of Russia. The Caspian Sea - The world's largest inland water body.

question: Which is the highest plateau in the world ? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Tibet plateau (Roof of the world) is the largest and highest plateau in the world. It is a vast elevated plateau located at the intersection of Central, South and East Asia.

question: In ‘Andes Mountain’ of South America animals which are used for transportation is ______ . SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Llamas {Scientiﬁc name: Lama glama, Trophic level: Herbivorous}. Longest Mountain Ranges: Andes (South America, longest continental mountain}, Rockies (North America), Great Dividing Range (Australia), Transantarctic Mountains (Antarctica), Atlas Mountains (Africa) etc.

question: Death Valley is a desert valley in the ________ that is the hottest and driest place with a world record highest air temperature of 134°F. SSC CHSL 08/06/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Mojave Desert of California. Death Valley is a desert valley in the northern Mojave Desert, bordering the Great Basin Desert. Rivers: Furnace Creek; Amargosa River.

question: Which country has the most time zones in the world? SSC MTS 13/10/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: France (12). Russia has 11 time zones, the United Kingdom has 1 time zone and India has only one-time zone.

question: A major portion of 'Sufed Koh' mountain range lies in ______. SSC CHSL 09/8/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Pakistan. Safed Koh is a mountain range on the Pakistan -Afghanistan border. It parallels the Kabul River. A spur of the range is crossed by the Khyber Pass.

question: A mass of snow and ice that moves slowly under the inﬂuence of gravity along a conﬁned course away from its place of accumulation is called a ______. SSC CHSL 09/8/2021(Evening)

solution.explanation: Glacier is a slowly moving mass or river of ice formed by the accumulation and compaction of snow on mountains or near the poles. A plateau is a ﬂat area of land that is elevated above sea level. Miscellaneous

question: A section of an active fault that has produced earthquakes in the past but is now quiet and is believed that the fault segment is capable of producing earthquake on some other basis is known as: SSC MTS 14/10/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Seismic Gap - A section of an active fault which has the potential to produce signiﬁcant earthquakes. Hypocenter: The point of origin of an earthquake beneath the Earth's surface where the fault rupture begins, representing the actual location where seismic energy is ﬁrst released. Epicenter: The point on the Earth's surface directly above the hypocenter, marking the geographical location where an earthquake's shaking is typically most intense and ﬁrst felt. Seismic Wave: The energy waves generated and propagated through the Earth's crust during an earthquake, which can be classiﬁed into different types like P-waves, S-waves, and surface waves that cause ground motion.

question: The earthquakes that are generated due to the explosion of chemical or nuclear devices are known as: SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Explosion earthquakes. Types of Earthquakes: In regions with heavy mining activity, the collapse of underground mine roofs can cause minor tremors, known as collapse earthquakes. The most common type is tectonic earthquakes, which result from the movement of rocks along a fault plane. A subcategory of tectonic earthquakes, known as volcanic earthquakes, occur in areas with active volcanoes. Additionally, reservoir-induced earthquakes are triggered in regions where large reservoirs are present.

question: In which year was Project Tiger launched in India? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: On April 1, 1973, Project Tiger was oﬃcially launched at the Corbett Tiger Reserve, initially including nine tiger reserves. International Tiger Day is celebrated annually on July 29. The Wildlife Protection Act was passed in 1972. Projects in India related to animals :Project Hangul (1970), Project Crocodile (1975), Project Elephant (1992), Project Rhino (2005), Project Gangetic Dolphin - (2009), Project Snow Leopard (2009), Project Great Indian Bustard (2012).

question: Which of the following can be represented as a functional unit of nature? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ecosystem. This is because an ecosystem encompasses all living organisms (plants, animals, and microorganisms) interacting with each other and with the non-living components (like air, water, and soil) within their environment. These interactions allow for energy ﬂow, nutrient cycling, and the maintenance of life-supporting processes, which are critical functions of nature.

question: Which of the following is a man-made ecosystem? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Aquarium. It is a facility or park where a collection of aquatic animals and plants is maintained for study, conservation, and public display. A man-made ecosystem, also known as an artiﬁcial or anthropogenic ecosystem, refers to a human-created environment where biotic and abiotic components interact to sustain life. Examples of man-made ecosystems include tree plantations, urban landscapes, crop ﬁelds, managed ponds, zoos, and gardens.

question: Which of the following are the two basic categories of an ecosystem? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Terrestrial and Aquatic. An ecosystem is a chain of interactions between organisms and their environment. The term "ecosystem" was ﬁrst coined by English botanist A.G. Tansley in 1935. A terrestrial ecosystem refers to a land-based community of www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography organisms and the interactions between biotic and abiotic components in a speciﬁc area. An aquatic ecosystem involves interacting organisms that rely on each other and their water environment for nutrients and shelter.

question: Which branch of ecology deals with the characteristics of the ancient environment and their relationship with ancient plants and animals? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Paleoecology studies past ecosystems and their changes over time using fossils and geological data. Other branches: Demecology (ecology of populations), Ichthyology (study of ﬁshes), and Mycology (study of fungi).

question: Which of the following is the best deﬁnition of ecological eﬃciency? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.A: The amount of energy utilised at
options.B: The amount of energy stored at
options.C: The ratio between the mass and the
options.D: The ratio between energy ﬂows at

solution.correct_answer: D. The ratio between energy ﬂows at
solution.explanation: Ecological eﬃciency describes the eﬃciency with which energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next. The number of trophic levels in the grazing food chain is restricted as the transfer of energy follows 10 percent law - only 10 percent of the energy is transferred to each trophic level from the lower trophic level.

question: The record obtained by the measurement of earthquake is called a: SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: seismogram. Earthquakes are classiﬁed into three zones based on depth: shallow (0-70 km), intermediate (70-300 km), and deep (300-700 km). The vibrations produced during an earthquake are known as seismic waves.

question: The Environment (Protection) Act, 1986 empowers the _________ to establish authorities charged with the mandate of preventing environmental pollution in all its forms. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Central Government. The Environment (Protection) Act, 1986 was enacted to safeguard and enhance the environment. The Central Government has the authority to: protect and improve the environment, set emission and discharge standards, regulate industrial locations, manage hazardous wastes, and protect public health and welfare. Some key environmental acts include the Biological Diversity Act (2002), Wild Life (Protection) Act (1972), Forest Conservation Act (1980), Indian Forest Act (1927), and Energy Conservation Act (2001).

question: Who introduced the concept of virtual water? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: John Anthony Allan. Virtual water is the freshwater used to produce goods or services, which is then traded internationally as part of those products.

question: In which of the following regions of India is the Mundari language spoken? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Chota-Nagpur plateau. This plateau covers parts of Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and West Bengal. Mundari is a Munda language, belonging to the Austroasiatic language family. Chhota Nagpur plateau is called the “Heart of industrial India” because it is rich in minerals and power fuels. The highest mountain peak of Chota Nagpur Plateau is Parasnath.

question: Which Greek term was ﬁrst used by Ernst Haeckel in 1866 to refer to ‘the relation of animals to both the organic as well as the inorganic environment’? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Oekologie. Ernst Haeckel, a German biologist and philosopher, made signiﬁcant contributions to evolutionary biology. He coined terms like "ecology," "phylogeny," and "Protista" and is known for his recapitulation theory, stating that an organism's development mirrors its species' evolutionary history.

question: Which of the following is the characteristics of epilimnion? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Thermal stratiﬁcation occurs when the water in a lake forms distinct layers through heating from the sun. It led to the separation of the lake into three layers. Epilimnion: The upper layer of warmer water. Metalimnion: The middle layer with a zone of gradual decrease in temperature. Hypolimnion: The bottom layer of colder water.

question: The depositional pattern of CaCO3 and other materials that extend upwards from the ﬂoor of a limestone cavern is known as: SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Stalagmite. It rises up from the ﬂoor of the caves. Stalactite - It is an icicle-shaped formation that hangs from the ceiling of a cave and is produced by the precipitation of minerals from water dripping through the cave ceiling. The stalagmites and stalactites eventually fuse to give rise to columns and pillars of different diameters.

question: Epilimnetic, metalimnetic, and hypolimnetic water strata are example of: SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

options.B: typical thermal stratiﬁcation of a lake

solution.correct_answer: B. typical thermal stratiﬁcation of a lake
solution.explanation: typical thermal stratiﬁcation of a lake. These layers are referred to as Epilimnion (warm surface waters) - Top-most layer in a thermally stratiﬁed lake and Hypolimnion (cold bottom waters) which are separated by the metalimnion, or thermocline layer, a stratum of rapidly changing temperature.

question: In which of the following schedules of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 is the most common wild cat in India 'Felis chaus' listed? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Schedule II. Under this schedule, the species receives protection, and poaching or capturing it without proper authorization is prohibited. The Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972 is an Indian law enacted to protect plant and animal species.

question: What is a population (or subspecies or race) that is adapted to local environmental conditions called? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Ecotype is a genetically distinct group within a species adapted to speciﬁc environmental conditions. An ecological niche describes how a species interacts within an ecosystem. A biome refers to a community of plants and animals naturally occurring in a region with shared characteristics.

question: Identify whether the given statements about an earthquake are correct or incorrect. Statement 1 : When the stress on the edge overcomes the friction, there is an earthquake that releases energy in waves that travel through Earth's crust and causes the shaking that we feel. Statement 2 : An earthquake cannot be identiﬁed as a foreshock until after a larger earthquake in the same area occurs. SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. Both Statements 1 and 2 are correct
solution.explanation: Both Statements 1 and 2 are correct. When lithospheric plates move, the Earth's surface vibrates, causing earthquakes. The point inside the crust where movement begins is called the focus, while the point directly above it on the surface is the epicenter. Vibrations spread outward from the epicenter, with the strongest impact near this point, decreasing as they move away.

question: Of the total water content available globally, how much percentage of water is received from freshwater resources? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: 2.5%. Although 71% of the Earth's surface is covered by water, only 2.5% of it is freshwater. Out of total water resources on earth Ocean comprises 97.25%, Ice caps- 2.05%, Groundwater- 0.68%, Lakes- 0.1%, Soil moisture- 0.005% , Atmosphere- 0.001% , Streams and river- 0.0001% , Biosphere- 0.00004% . India accounts for about 2.45% of the world's surface area, 4% of the world's water resources, and approximately 16% of the global population.

question: The highly viscous, mechanically-weak and ductile region of Earth's upper mantle is called: Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: Asthenosphere. Lithosphere : The rigid outer layer of Earth, consisting of the crust and the uppermost part of the mantle. It is divided into tectonic plates. Mesosphere : The mesosphere is the third highest layer of atmosphere and occupies the region above the stratosphere and below the thermosphere. Exosphere : The outermost layer of Earth's atmosphere, where air is extremely thin, and particles can escape into space.

question: ____________ is the study of the distribution and movement of water both on and below the Earth’s surface, as well as the impact of human activity on water availability and conditions. Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Hydrology. Different Branches and Their Studies: Bryology - The Study of Bryophytes. Biology - The study of living things and their vital processes. Floriculture - The Study of ﬂowers and ﬂowering plants. Ecology - The Study of inter-relationship between living and their environment.

question: Which of the following is NOT considered a method of conservation of natural resources? Graduate Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: Extraction refers to the process of removing natural resources from the Earth, such as mining, drilling for oil, or harvesting timber. Conservation is the proper management of a natural resource to prevent its exploitation, destruction or degradation. Method of conservation of Natural Resources : Reforestation, Rainwater Harvesting, Treatment of Industrial Eﬄuents, In-Situ conservation of Biodiversity, Ex-Situ conservation of Biodiversity, Sustainable development, Crop rotation, Contour ploughing, etc.

question: The Vienna Convention is related to ____________. Graduate Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 3) a) protection of wild life

solution.explanation: protection of ozone layer. The Vienna Convention multilateral environmental agreement was signed in 1985, came into effect in 1988, and achieved universal ratiﬁcation by 2009. The primary goal of the Vienna Convention is to safeguard human health and the environment from the harmful effects caused by ozone layer depletion.

question: Select the correct statement. Graduate Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

options.A: The pyramid of energy is always
options.B: The pyramid of biomass is always
options.C: The pyramid of mass is always
options.D: The pyramid of number is always

solution.correct_answer: A. The pyramid of energy is always
solution.explanation: The pyramid of energy is always upright, and can never be inverted. According to the 10% law proposed by Raymond Lindeman of energy ﬂow, only 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to another and 90% of the energy remains at the former trophic level for its needs like respiration and digestion processes. The direction of energy ﬂow in an ecosystem is always unidirectional.

question: Select the correct statement about climax community. Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

options.A: It is an ecological community in
options.B: It is a very ﬁrst community of the
options.C: It consists of only plant population
options.D: It is an ecological community in which

solution.correct_answer: D. It is an ecological community in which
solution.explanation: A climax community is the “endpoint” of succession within the context of a particular climate and geography. The climax community remains stable as long as the environment remains unchanged. www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography

question: Which concept was proposed by Hutchinson in 1957 to express the relationship of an individual or population to all aspects of its environment? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Ecological niche - A term for the position of a species within an ecosystem. It refers to the Interrelationship of a species with all the biotic and abiotic factors affecting it.

question: Which of the following companies had constructed Asia’s ﬁrst cross - country pipeline as a mode of transport for liquids and gasses over long distances ? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Oil India Limited. Naharkatia (Assam)-Barauni (Bihar) Pipeline (First cross-country pipeline). The Pipeline between Naharkatia and Nunmati became operative in 1962 and that between Nunmati and Barauni in 1964.

question: The term physical geology was coined by __________. SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: William Hopkins. Fathers of Various Fields - Economics (Adam Smith), Telephone (Alexander Graham Bell), Modern Chemistry (Antoine Lavoisier), Classiﬁcation/ Taxonomy (Carl Linnaeus), Evolution (Charles Darwin), Geography (Eratosthenes).

question: Who was the ﬁrst ecologist to describe the speciﬁc shape of eco-trophic interactions, which he called the pyramid of numbers, in the 1920s ? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Charles Elton. He introduced the concept of food web, food chain and ecological niche in the classic textbook “Animal Ecology” in 1927. Ernest Haeckel - He coined the term ‘Ecology’ in 1866. Edward O Wilson - Proponent of Sociobiology.

question: The Karewa formations are found in the __________ . SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Kashmir Himalayas. The Karewa term means “elevated table land”. Firstly, this term was used by Godwin Austin in 1859. “Vudr” is the local name for it in Kashmiri language. Karewa formations are useful for the cultivation of Zafran (Saffron), almond, walnut, apple, and orchards in Kashmir valley.

question: Siachen in Himalayas is: SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: A glacier. The Siachen Glacier is located in the Eastern Karakoram range in the Himalayas. It is the world's highest battleﬁeld. Nubra river originates from Siachen Glacier. It is situated to the North of Nubra Valley.

question: ____________ is characterized by abundant dissolved oxygen, sunlight, nutrients, generally high wave energies and water motion, and, in the intertidal subzone, alternating submergence and exposure. SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: The Littoral Zone - It is an area close to the shore and submerged in water to some degree. Lentic Zone - Ecosystem entails a body of standing water, ranging from ditches, seeps, ponds, seasonal pools, basin marshes and lakes. Benthic Zone - The lowest ecological zone in a water body. Limnetic zone - The top layer of lake water distant from the coast, and extends only as deep as sunlight can penetrate (200 m).

question: Which ecologist showed in a long-term experiment on outdoor plots that biodiversity is of central importance to the productivity, stability, resistance to the invasion of ecosystems and fertility of their soils? SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: David Tilman. Edward O. Wilson - Father of biodiversity. Karl Möbius - First to develop the concept of ecological community, biocenosis, or living community.

question: Which hypothesis was proposed by Paul Ehrlich to suggest the importance of species richness in the maintenance of ecosystems ? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Rivet popper hypothesis. The hypothesis suggests the importance of species richness in the maintenance of the ecosystem. Redundancy hypothesis - It predicts that the species redundancy in a plant community enhances community stability. Predation hypothesis - It predicts that group-living animals are adapted to make alarm calls that distract or confuse predators.

question: Which states are involved in the joint venture of the Chambal Project? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh. Chambal Project : Initiated in - 1954. Aim - Harnessing the Chambal River for irrigation, Power generation and for prevention and control of soil erosion in the valley.

question: In the context of ecology, the given equation shows the relationship between the size of an area and the number of species present in it. Accordingly, by which letter is the regression coeﬃcient denoted? log S = log C + Z log A SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Z. The species-area relationship is often evaluated in conservation science in order to predict extinction rates in the case of habitat loss and habitat fragmentation. The equation: log S = log C + Z log A, where S = species richness, A = area, C = Y-intercept.

question: In the 1930s, which of the following theories was propounded by Arthur Holmes about the mantle ? SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Convectional current Theory. The Convectional currents are generated due to radioactive elements causing thermal differences in the mantle portion. Arthur Holmes - The ﬁrst earth scientist to grasp the mechanical and thermal implications of mantle convection, which led eventually to the acceptance of plate tectonics.

question: Name a unit designed for wet and dry bulb thermometers to protect temperature sensors from being affected by direct or reﬂected sunlight. SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Stevenson screen - It is also known as a cotton region shelter, an instrument shelter, a thermometer shelter, a thermoscreen, or a thermometer screen. Skywarn screen - It is a national network of volunteer severe weather spotters. It was established to obtain critical weather information by the National Weather Service.

question: Which state is also known as the 'Molasses basin', which is made up of soft unconsolidated deposits? SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Mizoram (The Land of rolling mountains). Manipur is known as ‘The Jewel of land’ in India. Nagaland - The falcon capital of the world. Meghalaya - The Abode of Clouds.

question: In which year was an approach and program named Joint Forest Management (JFM) launched in the context of National Forest Policy? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: 1988. Joint Forest Management is about involving local communities in the management and restoration of degraded forests.

question: Eugene Odum is well known for: Graduate Level 30/06/2023 ( Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Contribution in ecology. Eugene Pleasants Odum (Father of modern ecology). Alexander von Humbolt - Father of ecology. Arthur G. Tansley - First to coin the term ecosystem in 1935. Vladimir Vernadsky - Founded the biosphere concept.

question: Which of the following is the scientiﬁc discipline concerned with the description and classiﬁcation of the Earth's topographic features? SSC CHSL Tier-2 26/06/2023

solution.explanation: Geomorphology is a term that studies change in the earth’s surface due to these exogenic and endogenic forces, where exogenic forces are the external forces originating within the earth’s atmosphere and endogenic forces are internal forces generated from within the earth. Acarology - Study of mites and ticks. It also involves the study of the Acarina order - it means study of arachnids like spiders, scorpions,etc.

question: _______ species are those species of plants and animals which are found exclusively in a particular area. SSC MTS 10/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Endemic. Example of Endemic Species - Kangaroos originally endemic to Australia and found nowhere else in the world. Endemic Species of India - Asiatic Lion (Gir Forest), Kashmir Stag (Kashmir Valley), Purple Frog (Western Ghats), Sangai Deer (Loktak Lake), Nilgiri Tahr (Nilgiri Hills).

question: In countries like Japan, _________ birth rates make the population pyramid _______ at the base. SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Low, Narrow. A population pyramid is a way to visualize age and sex of a speciﬁc population. Decreased Death rates allow numbers of people to reach old age. A country in which birth and death rates are high, the pyramid is broad at the base and rapidly narrows towards the top (Kenya).

question: Which is the second largest family in modern Indian languages? SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Dravidian (Dravida). Major Dravidian Languages - Tamil, Telugu, Kannada and Malayalam. They are mainly spoken in southern India, central India, north-east Sri Lanka.

question: The point on the surface, nearest to the focus of the earthquake, is called _______. SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Epicenter. Hypocenter - A point beneath the Earth's surface where the vibrations of an earthquake originate. Richter scale is the most common standard of measurement for earthquakes. The Richter Magnitude - It is a measure of the amount of energy released during an earthquake and expressed by the Richter scale.

question: Identify the southernmost range of the Himalaya from the following. SSC MTS 14/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Siwaliks Range. Himalayan Ranges: Himadri (Greater Himalayas or Inner Himalayas), Himachal (Lesser Himalayas), Shiwaliks (Outer Himalayas). Divisions (West to east) : Punjab Himalayas (between rivers Indus and Sutlej), Kumaon Himalayas (Between Sutlej and Kali rivers), Nepal Himalayas (between rivers Kali and Teesta), Assam Himalayas (between rivers Tista and Dihang), Purvanchal (beyond the Dihang river).

question: The western Ghats and the Eastern Ghats meet at which of the following places in southern India? SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Nilgiri Hills: Highest Peak - Doda Betta. Located at the tri-junction of the states of Karnataka, Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Named after the Neelakurinji ﬂowers (purplish-blue ﬂowers) found in Shola forests. Satpura Hills - The range begins in eastern Gujarat and runs east through Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh before ending in Chhattisgarh. Nallamala Hills - Andhra Pradesh, eastern ghats. Mahendragiri Hills is located in the district of Gajapati, Odisha (eastern ghats).

question: Which of the following earthquake www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Geography waves are longitudinal waves? SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: P waves. They vibrate parallel to the direction of the wave. This exerts pressure on the material in the direction of the propagation. Earthquake waves (Seismic waves) are vibrations in the earth that transmit energy.

question: ___________species are the species which are not found after searches of known or likely areas where they may occur. SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Extinct. An endangered species is a type of organism that is threatened by extinction. Examples: Black Rhino, Tiger, Whale, Red Panda, Chimpanzee, Asian Elephant etc.

question: Which of the following is a vulnerable species? SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Asiatic elephant. A vulnerable species is a species which has been categorized by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as being threatened with extinction.

question: Which of the following pairs of "term - deﬁnition" is correct? I. Strait - a narrow strip of land joining two landmasses II. Isthmus - a narrow passage of water connecting two large water bodies SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (4th Shift)

options.C: Neither I nor II (d) Only I

solution.correct_answer: C. Neither I nor II (d) Only I
solution.explanation: Neither I nor II. Strait - Narrow body of water that connects two larger bodies of water, Examples - Cook strait (New Zealand), Malacca strait (Indonesia-Malaysia), Mesina strait (Italy-Sicily), Bering strait (Alaska -Russia), Hormuz strait (Gulf of Persia-Gulf of Oman), etc. Isthmus - Narrow strip of land that connects two larger landmasses and separates two bodies of water, Examples - Isthmus of Panama, Isthmus of Suez.

question: In 1962, who published 'The History of Ocean Basins', which outlined the theory of how tectonic plates could move, later called 'sea ﬂoor spreading'? SSC CGL Tier II 03/03/2023

solution.explanation: Harry Hammond Hess. According to the theory of plate tectonics, the earth’s lithosphere is broken into distinct plates which are ﬂoating on a ductile layer called asthenosphere.

question: The national census does NOT recognise ________ groups within India. SSC CGL Tier II 06/03/2023

solution.explanation: Ethnic. Census is the process of collecting, analyzing, and sharing demographic, economic, and social data of all people in a country or speciﬁc region at a given time.

question: Which of the following mountains is formed as a result of the compression of tectonic plates, leading to the formation of large fold-like structures on the Earth's crust? SSC CHSL 25/05/2022(Evening)

solution.explanation: Ural mountain in Russia. Fold Mountains - Himalayan Mountains in Asia, the Alps in Europe, the Andes in South America, the Rockies in North America.

question: Which of the following mountains were formed when molten rock from the depths of the earth rose from the crust and piled up on its own? SSC CHSL 31/05/2022(Evening)

solution.explanation: Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa (Tanzania). Top mountains in Africa:- Mount Kenya, Mount Stanley, Mount Speke, Mount Baker, Mount Emin.

question: 'Anaconda' , one of the world's largest snakes, is found in _______. SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Tropical Evergreen Forests (Amazon forest). They are categorized under the genus Eunectes (great swimmers) and family (Boidae). They thrive very well in hot, humid places with dense foliage. Tropical rainforests are found in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia around the equator.

question: Which ﬂoating fern damages aquatic ecosystems by outgrowing and replacing native plants that provide food and habitat for native animals and waterﬂow? Graduate Level 01/08/2022 ( Shift - 4 )

solution.explanation: Giant salvinia (aquatic fern, native to south-eastern Brazil, Scientiﬁc name - Salvinia molesta). Salvinia minima (common salvinia or water spangles), Osmunda regalis (Royal fern), Azolla pinnata (mosquito fern, feathered mosquito fern and water velvet).

question: ___________ refers to a sanitation system in which toilets collect human excreta in sealable, removable cartridges that are transported to treatment facilities. SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Container Based Sanitation. Ecological sanitation is that protects human and ecosystem health while preventing water pollution, conserving energy, and capturing nutrients.
